password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsExclusive: The study marks the death knell for&nbsptraditional class-based views of how voters actClick to followIndy PoliticsExperts have devised a revolutionary new system for classifying voters that could hand political parties the key to unlocking victory at the next general election, The Independent can reveal.The project headed by BMG Research drives a horse and carriage through traditional class-based views of how voters act and instead ides them into 10 electoral “clans”.After interviewing almost 30,000 people over a year, researchers identified the distinct values of each clan and the issues on which they overlap – with parties able to politically position themselves on these sweet spots, standing to gain the backing of multiple groups.Backing Remain would risk abandoning Labour’s working-class votersToday BMG are launching a new online tool exclusively with The Independent, which allows anyone to discover which clan they belong to and to access data pointing to how groups may vote come 2022.The study, a collaboration with academics in Bristol and Manchester, also offers a valuable insight into the politics of Brexit, which have cleaved through the traditional voting coalitions relied on by the major parties.Dr Michael Turner, BMG’s research director and the report’s lead author, said: “All political parties are coalitions of voters with different priorities, and these coalitions are changing.“The old way of looking at the world, through demographic factors such as social class, age, education, and where we live – all have much smaller influences on the way we vote compared to values and identity politics.“The research team have also created an incredibly powerful and engaging tool, so the public can understand for themselves, what these clans are and how they differ, revealing the siloed and fractured nature of our politics at this time.”The study interviewed 27,000 people to identify the “like-minded values groups”, and then devised 27 “golden questions” which if answered by any voter allows them to be categorised into one of the clans.(If you cannot access the interactive questionnaire above it can be completed here.)Identified groups include those such as the “Bastions of Tradition and&nbspthe Inidual” clan, the “Strength, Agreeable and Respect” clan, the “Modern Working Life” group and the “Notting Hill Society”.The biggest single clan is the “Proud and Patriotic State”, making up some 15 per cent of the voting public and tending to favour redistribution of wealth, nationalisation of key industries and with a strong dislike of multiculturalism and freedom of movement.Next biggest is the “Common Sense Solidarity” clan, which are&nbspalso strong supporters of renationalisation and trade unions and believe firmly in the redistribution of wealth via taxation.But while these two groups share a desire for left-wing economic policy, they are fundamentally ided over multiculturalism, with “Common Sense Solidarity” members far more at ease with immigration – the two groups were on opposite sides of the Brexit debate.Created with Sketch.The ten voter Understanding the ‘clans’ offers valuable insights into who might want what from Brexit and how this might affect future elections, or indeed referendum outcomes.”Between the 2015 and 2017 election both Labour and the Tories increased their share in many of the groups, squeezing out smaller parties.Created with Sketch.How big are the UK's voter clans and how do they vote? growth in turnout from liberal, left-of-centre groups, the “Global Green Community”, up by almost 8 per cent, and “Common Sense Solidarity”, up by more than 4 per cent – with both groups overwhelmingly falling in behind Mr Corbyn’s Labour.Overall the Conservatives were ahead across a greater range of groups – in seven of the 10 clans three years ago, down to six last year.The only group that changed allegiance was the “Orange Book” clan – connected to Nick Clegg’s Liberal Democrats – which tipped from overall support for the Tories in 2015, to marginal backing for Labour in 2017.It is these findings that led researchers behind the report to conclude the key factor in the 2017 result was not a “youthquake” – a spike in turnout among young people inspired by Mr Corbyn – but a “liberal tremor”, those with liberal views turning out in greater numbers and switching to backing the Labour leader.The tool, useable on this page, allows anyone to answer the 27 “golden story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAcademic suggests prime minister deliberately misquoted him in order to 'gain political effect' in attack on LabourClick to followIndy PoliticsA leading economist has accused Theresa May of lying&nbspduring Prime Minister's Questions, claiming she&nbspdeliberately misquoted him.Simon Wren-Lewis, a professor at Oxford University, strongly denied&nbspthe prime minister's suggestion that he had said the&nbspfigures in Labour's last manifesto did not add up.The claim appeared to be&nbspa deliberate&nbsplie told to gain political effect, he said.Ms May made the comment during a clash with Jeremy Corbyn at&nbspPMQs on Wednesday.Sterling falls to six-week low as Theresa May faces Brexit backlashShe did not directly name Mr Wren-Lewis&nbspbut referred to a chapter he wrote&nbspfor&nbspa book, titled Economics for the Many, that was edited by John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor.&nbspMr Wren-Lewis is&nbspan informal adviser to Mr McDonnell.Mr Wren-Lewis hit back within minutes, denying that he had&nbspsaid Labour's figures were wrong. Instead, he said, he had argued that claims by the Institute for Fiscal Studies&nbspthat&nbspthe party's costings contained factual mistakes were irrelevant.He wrote on Twitter: Apparently the prime minister quoted me saying about Labour's 2017 manifesto 'the numbers did not add up'. In fact I said 'let us suppose the IFS was correct' and examined consequences. I have never taken a view on whether they diddidn't add up. If that is what she said, she lied.In a blog post titled The day Theresa May lied in parliament about something I wrote, he continued: The point I wanted to stress was that it didn’t matter if the IFS were right that the numbers didn’t add up, because the fiscal stance was good for the economy, and could well satisfy Labour's very good Fiscal Credibility Rule.Of the prime minister's comments, he said: Was this an unfortunate case of misreading? It seems extremely implausible. I’m certain that when the PM or more probably some adviser misquotes someone in a draft PMQ response, someone - possibly even the person themselves - checks that the quote is correct. You have to have serious comprehension difficulties to misunderstand the meaning of 'let us suppose'.He suggested Ms May's claim was a deliberate&nbsplie told to gain political effect but said he would be&nbspwilling to accept it was an honest mistake if the prime minister&nbspor someone from her team could explain how it happened.&nbspHe said: In the scheme of things the issue is very minor, but the prime minister&nbsplying whatever the context should be important. But the sad thing is that no one is surprised by this kind of thing any more.We in the UK look at Trump’s lying with horror and think this is something uniquely American. But this government has been pulled up countless time&nbspfor misleading the public by misusing statistics and of course the lies of the Brexiters are shameless.Mr Wren-Lewis said he had&nbspasked the Conservative Party for an apology but was not holding my breath.The matter was raised in the Commons by Peter Dowd, the shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, who suggested Ms May should apologise.Khan warns Labour MPs not to 'blackmailed' over PM's Brexit dealUK to 'revoke Saudi suspects' visas today' over Khashoggi's murderMay confirms she will attend showdown meeting with Tory rebelsMay sidesteps rebels with plans to enshrine Brexit proposal in lawMaking a point of order, he said: During Prime Minister’s Questions, the prime minister asserted that the respected Oxford economist and professor, Simon Wren-Lewis, said, in reference to Labour’s manifesto, 'the numbers did not add up'.However, Professor Wren-Lewis disputes the accuracy of those remarks.Quoting&nbspthe academic's tweet, he added: Would it be appropriate for the prime minister to come back to this House to correct the record and apologise to the renowned professor in question?The deputy speaker, Eleanor Laing,&nbspsaid she was sure Ms May's comments were made in good faith and that&nbspit was not her job to assess the accuracy of claims made in the Commons.No 10 has been contacted for story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'Let’s face it, they would not have dared to do what they did in Istanbul in America,' says&nbspfriend of murdered journalist&nbspClick to followThe IndependentThe journalist’s murder has been met with widespread condemnationJamal Khashoggi was told by Saudi officials&nbsphe would not be able to get his orce documents in the US in order to get married&nbspand needed to go to Turkey, as part of&nbspa ploy to bring him within reach for abduction or elimination, it has been claimed.The journalist was directed to the Kingdom’s legations in Turkey because those plotting against him believed it would be far too risky to try to carry out an attack in America, with potentially hugely damaging&nbsprepercussions, according to diplomatic sources and a friend of Mr Khashoggi.&nbspHaving been told initially&nbsphe would be able to pick up the legal papers in the Saudi embassy in Washington, Mr Khashoggi was advised&nbsphe had to obtain them in Turkey for a&nbspforthcoming wedding to his fiancée Hatice Cengiz, who is a Turkish citizen, with the ceremony due to be held in Turkey.Did they bury Jamal Khashoggi with his body facing Mecca?US intelligence, a number of news organisations have claimed, had intercepted that Saudi officials had been planning to lure Mr Khashoggi back to the Kingdom and then arrest him.&nbsp &nbspIt is unclear when the intelligence was gathered, but there appeared to have been no moves to warn Mr Khashoggi&nbsphe was in danger and that a trap may have been laid for him. &nbspIt is known a number of officials close to Crown Prince&nbspMohammed bin Salman, known as MBS, had repeatedly asked the journalist to return to the Kingdom, with offers of lucrative and prestigious jobs – approaches Mr Khashoggi had rebuffed. &nbspHis visits to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul to get the documents, according to Turkish investigators, presented the Saudis with the opportunity they were seeking to seize and kill him. &nbspA friend of Mr Khashoggi said: “Jamal had been to the embassy in DC several times and they had dealt with his consular issues there. He thought he could get the documents he needed showing he was orced, a legal requirement, from the people in Washington. I think they told him it was a simple matter. The Saudi government claimed that Mr al-Qahtani was fired after Khashoggi’s killing, along with another senior official. Eighteen others have been arrested.Mr al-Qahtani, it has been reported, led the interrogation of Lebanese Prime Minister Saad Hariri when he was detained in Saudi Arabia last year after being enticed to the country to meet the crown prince.&nbspThe questioning, it has been claimed, was accompanied by verbal and physical abuse. He had told friends that the ambassador had been amiable and pleasant.Prince Khaled, known as KBS, flew to Saudi Arabia after Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance in Istanbul and has not returned to the US. &nbspIn a text message sent to a number of people in Washington, and disseminated later to the media, the ambassador said that Khashoggi “has many friends in the Kingdom, including myself” and had “maintained regular contact when he was in Washington ... Jamal is a Saudi citizen whose safety and security is a top priority for the Kingdom, just as is the case with any other citizen. We will not spare any efforts to locate him.”There is no suggestion that Prince Khaled had played any part in Khashoggi travelling to Istanbul from Washington for his papers.Turkey’s President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has charged that Mr Khashoggi had been targeted in a Saudi plot which had been in place for a long time. On Thursday authorities in Riyadh stated that Khashoggi’s murder was premeditated.&nbspThis was yet another change of stance from the Kingdom’s government, which had firstly claimed that the journalist had left the consulate by a back door (a Saudi official was later found to have been impersonating him doing this) and then that he was killed during a “fist fight”. story: The grant will help organisations working with vulnerable EU citizens who need extra support, the Home Office said.Voluntary and community organisations will use the money to inform people about settled-status applications.It will also be used to help people complete their applications.Around 3.2 million EU citizens live in the UK, with 1.3 million Brits across the EU.                &lsquoWe need a plan B that works&rsquo Tory MP offers alternative Brexit PlanMore than 3.2 million EU citizens live in the UK, with around 1.2 million Brits in the EU (Image: Getty)A pilot government scheme for 250,000 of EU residents to test the post-Brexit registration process was launched in October.Immigration Minister Caroline Nokes said: EU citizens are our neighbours, our friends and our family and we want them to stay.It is essential that those who are more vulnerable and require support are able to access the help that they need.This funding and our work with the voluntary and community sector will help ensure that every EU citizen who is eligible to stay has their status protected. title: no deal Brexit explained what does no deal brexit mean for house prices
story: After years of positive growth, UK house prices grew at the slowest rate in five years in August 2018.With Brexit looming, existing owners, as well as potential buyers, are concerned about the political and economic uncertainties and the knock-on effect on the housing market.With the Budget coming up next week, all eyes are on Philip Hammond to set out how the government will protect the economy in the case of a no-deal Brexit.And the clock is ticking: The UK is set to leave the EU at 11pm on March 29, and with negotiations faltering repeatedly, the chances if a no-deal Brexit seem increasingly likely.                NO DEAL BREXIT EXPLAINED: What could no-deal Brexit mean for food?                Will May survive until the Budget? PM faces her toughest week yet                 Brexit backstop EXPLAINED: Why the Northern Ireland border is crucialNo deal Brexit explained: The governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney (Image: Getty)There is the further concern that people will be hesitant to buy properties, sending the market into a deeper downward spiral.&ldquoBecause it will be a time of uncertainty, it&rsquos likely that people will be more cautious about making commitments such as buying property and buying conditions may become more difficult, Ms Morris said.&ldquoIt&rsquos likely larger landlords will acquire properties as they will be able to spread the risk.But it&rsquos not all doom and gloom.The Bank of England routinely carries out stress tests to check whether the banking system can withstand extreme financial shocks.No deal Brexit explained: After years of positive growth, UK house prices grew slowly in 2018 (Image: Getty)The last one was conducted in&nbspNovember,&nbspwhen it said 33&nbsppercent&nbspfall in house prices could occur in a worst-case scenario.But this isn&rsquot a guarantee.The BBC&rsquos economics editor, Kamal Ahmed, explained: &ldquoIt was not a forecast.&ldquoIt was an apocalyptic test where the Bank deliberately sets the parameters beyond what might reasonably be expected to occur.&ldquoThe major banks all passed the test, giving reassurance that the financial system can cope with whatever happens next year.

story: Brexit news: a petition to stop a People's Vote has gained tens of thousands of signatures (Image: )The petition, launched by Ronald Mitchell on the official parliamentary petitions website, has already reached more than 30,000 supporters at the time of writing - and is continuing to rise by the minute.In contrast, a petition for a &ldquoreferendum to join the EU on the 30th of March 2019 had garnered a mere 82 signatures at the time of writing.The apparent dwindling of public appetite for a second Brexit vote comes after a YouGov poll released on Tuesday, October 23, stated under a quarter of Remain voters now anticipate a re-run of the 2016 vote.In response to the petition - amid fading support for a so-called People&rsquos Vote - a number of MEPs have spoken to Express to voice their anger and frustration at those acting &ldquolike spoilt children.Reacting to the news, Independent MEP for North East England Jonathan Arnott said: &ldquoThe people voted in the 2014 European elections, the 2015 General Election, the 2016 referendum, and the 2017 General Election.&ldquoWe don&rsquot need a fifth vote, people don&rsquot want one, and there isn&rsquot time for one.&ldquoWe&rsquore five months from Brexit, yet Electoral Commission rules require a six-month campaign period for any referendum.&ldquoThe EU won&rsquot agree to extend Article 50 because it would mess up the European Elections across the whole EU next year.Brexit news: an estimated 500,000 people turned out to protest against Brexit last weekend (Image: )&ldquoThe whole idea of another referendum is illogical, destabilising and doomed to failure.&ldquoI&rsquom delighted that this petition recognises political reality.West Midlands MEP Bill Etheridge also voiced his concern over those acting &ldquolike spoilt children demanding a second referendum.The Libertarian Party UK Deputy Chairman said: &ldquoOnce again a vocal minority is trying to defy the will of the people.                Labour peer MOCKS organisers of second Brexit referendum march                Carole Malone destroys May's Brexit efforts and calls for new leaderProtestors blame hard-line Brexiteers such as Jacob Rees-Mogg and Boris Johnson for Brexit (Image: )Labour's Chuka Umunna is a prominent advocate for a second Brexit referendum (Image: )&ldquo17.4m of us voted to leave - the biggest vote in UK history. If our voices are not listened to - or fudged by the atrocious Chequers sell-out, then representative democracy truly is dead.&ldquoWatching the Losers March on Saturday has exposed the fragility of our system to aggressive bullying.&ldquoLike spoilt children, they must not get their own way.John Flack, Conservative MEP for the East of England, argued pursuing a second Brexit vote was &ldquohigh-handed and &ldquopatronising as he called on &ldquoordinary voters to &ldquoslap down those calling for a people&rsquos vote.He said: &ldquoThe liberal elite in this country are becoming obsessive about their so-called People's Vote.The Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable is also a supporter of a re-run of the Brexit vote (Image: )&ldquoWe already had a referendum - THE referendum - and they lost.&ldquoTheir whole approach is high-handed, patronising and anti-democratic - so it is only right for ordinary voters to rally behind this petition and slap them down.Margot Parker, UKIP MEP for the East Midlands, also conveyed her frustration at attempts &ldquoto overturn democracy and hold another vote on the UK&rsquos membership of the EU bloc.She said: &ldquoIt is not a surprise to me that people are signing this petition to stop a second referendum.&ldquoWe voted to leave and the people signing this petition are tired of excuses from those in power who simply are not up to the task of getting us out of the EU.Thousands marched in London last weekend to 'demand a People's Vote' (Image: )&ldquoPeople are also growing weary at the constant attempts by some of those who voted to remain attempting to overturn democracy by holding another vote - some people simply will not rest until they get the decision they want to see - it's a betrayal of democracy.Amjad Bashir, Conservative MEP for Yorkshire and The Humber, argued &ldquoordinary voters were &ldquofurious at the people&rsquos vote proposal.He said: &ldquoI think a lot of ordinary voters are furious at the idea that some people didn't like the outcome of the first referendum so want another go.&ldquoThe British people won't be taken for fools and this petition is a way to vent their anger and make sure their decision is respected.

title: british legion poppy remembrance sunday
story: Incommunities, based in Bradford, Yorkshire, sent an email on October 19 telling employees to remove Remembrance Day Poppies and other &ldquopersonal touches from their work vehicles.According to the email, seen by the Bradford  and Argus, large poppies on front grilles of vehicle did not adhere to company policy.Other items in breach of the policy include flags, stickers and soft toys.An employee rang up the sender to double check if the rule applied to British Legion poppies and said he was told it did. But the furious backlash saw Incommunities hastily backtrack.&nbsp&nbsp                Wonderful...MBE joy of poppy seller Rose, 103                Poppy seller, 103, dies just days after getting MBEOne van driver said: &ldquoNone of us were happy.Another said: &ldquoI&rsquom absolutely outraged and disgusted.&ldquoI&rsquom that outraged I want to give my van back and I&rsquoll walk to my jobs.&ldquoThey sacrificed a lot for us and now, with it being the 100th anniversary, it&rsquos like sticking two fingers up at you.A housing firm in Bradford prompted backlash from employees by asking them to remove Poppies (Image: &bullALAMY)&ldquoI think it&rsquos just political correctness, not wanting to offend people. Why should it offend people in Britain? It&rsquos not just something new that we&rsquove started doing.&ldquoI&rsquom not going to take them off, they&rsquoll have to cut them off. I&rsquom going to get more now, bigger ones. It&rsquos an insult on people from the war.However after the furious backlash Incommunities later said the ban did not apply to poppies. They said they had sent a second email yesterday, four days after the initial message, clarifying this.A spokesman for Incommunities said this afternoon: &ldquoThe matter was raised and we clarified our position.The Poppy has long been a symbol of Remembrance for the heroes of World War I  (Image: )&ldquoA communication was issued yesterday explaining that we were happy for our drivers to display poppies on their vehicles in the lead up to Armistice Day and this is our position.The original email sent by Incommunities to over 1,200 employees in Bradford and Kirklee, seen by the Bradford  and Argus, said: &ldquoOver the past few weeks there have been an increased number of works vehicles with &lsquopersonal touches&rsquo being added to what is Incommunities property.&ldquoItems such as flags, stickers, scarves, soft toys and even large poppies on front grilles are appearing on a number of vehicles which is not in accordance with vehicle policy.&ldquoAs per page 4 section 1 of the Handbook all drivers must ensure vehicles are kept clean and tidy inside and out, cabin area clear of any obstructions.                Career criminal who stole POPPY APPEAL collection money avoids jailThis means clear of all paperwork on dashboards (dangerous with reflections) and also mean(s) that none of the aforementioned items are displayed in or on the vehicle either.&ldquoAll staff who drive a works vehicle should remove all stickers, flags, soft toys or any other paraphernalia which is not company issue.A statement issued today by an Incommunities spokesman said: &ldquoAs an organisation we always encourage all our staff to support the annual Poppy Appeal and wear their poppy with pride.&ldquoWe have Royal British Legion donation boxes with poppies at our main office, The Quays and are arranging deliveries of donation boxes to our three other bases.Employees at the Bradforf firm said the company was disrespcting the heroes of the Great War (Image: )&ldquoWe have raised many hundreds of pounds for the Royal British Legion over the years through staff and customer donations.&ldquoWe have had no restrictions on our drivers displaying poppies in previous years and all staff throughout the organisation are encouraged to wear poppies on their clothing.This year marks the 100th anniversary of the Poppy Appeal, which has raised money annually to offer lifelong support of the Armed Forces community since 1921.A spokesman for the Royal British Legion, who manufacture poppies at its factory in Richmond, south-west London, said the charity was grateful for every unit sold in the UK.The spokesman said: &ldquoWe are thankful for every poppy worn, every shop that allows poppy collections, and every employer that permits the poppy to be displayed - but we never insist upon these things or claim as our right. To do otherwise would be contrary to the spirit of Remembrance and all that the poppy stands for.

story: The Irish border resident exploded at Ireland's Government for rolling over in fear to the demands of the European Union.Mr Laighneach claimed Ireland has become a colony of the bloc, accepting its decision without criticism to avoid negative consequences.Speaking to RT UK, the peace activist said: I think the Irish rolled over in fear because our economy&rsquos tiny.I think there&rsquos bad leadership in Ireland, it&rsquos almost got to a stage where the European Union is now the new Holy Catholic Empire and any criticism of it now is almost blasphemy. And now comes the terrifying realisation that she has no backup plan.&ldquoShe&rsquos lost and what once her stubbornness was seen as the weapon with which to deliver Brexit, it&rsquos now the roadblock stopping it.&ldquoThe truth is Theresa May can&rsquot lead. And her lily-livered capitulation to the EU has destroyed her credibility and any chance of a good deal.&ldquoShe has to go.Britain needs a robust leader who has the guts to fight for Brexit that would be good for u, not the arrogant contentious clowns who run the EU.Brexit news: Carole Malone calls for Theresa May to resign over handling of Brexit negotiations (Image: SKY&bull)Ms Malone's strong criticism of the Prime Minister's Brexit strategy comes as Mrs May appeared to have seen off the threat of an imminent leadership challenge on Wednesday evening after Tory MPs put on a noisy show of support at a crunch backbench meeting.The Prime Minister was greeted by desk banging and thumping on wooden panelling - traditional indications of approval among Tory MPs - at the weekly gathering of the party's powerful 1922 Committee at Westminster.And while she faced a string of probing questions about her approach to the&nbspBrexit&nbsptalks, an attempt to trigger a vote of no-confidence in her leadership failed to materialise.Theresa May's allies insisted she had won the room and hoped the recent spate of speculation about coup plot had been laid to rest.One source close to the Prime Minister said: It was very supportive.But some critics complained the meeting had been staged managed by party whips.Mrs May faced the meeting of the 1922 Committee - made up off all the party's backbench MPs - following angry criticism of her concessions to the EU from Eurosceptics.Mrs May has faced anger from some Tories in recent days after refusing to rule out an extension to the 20-month post-Brexit transition period when the UK will remain closely tied to Brussels.MPs expecting a vote of no confidence in Mrs May&rsquos leadership were left disappointed. Rumours had swept Westminster in recent days that 1922 Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady had received at least 48 letters demanding the move, enough to trigger a confidence vote under party rules.But the matter was not raised by anyone during the meeting.

title: BBC Weather forecast UK weather update Met Office latest
story: The new weather front coming from the Arctic will hit the north of the UK on Thursday night and make its way through the rest of the country this weekend.&nbspBBC Weather forecaster Tomasz Schafernaker warned viewers to wrap up warm on Saturday as temperatures will reach single figures UK wide.&nbspHe said: &ldquoThis is expected to be the coldest weather since April of this year.&ldquoTemperatures widely across the country will be in the single figures and there will be a wind chill as well.                RECORD number of boiler breakdowns as ARCTIC air BLASTS Britain                UK Weather: Britain set for -5C temperatures as weather turns ARCTIC&ldquoOver the next few days and probably peaking around Saturday and Sunday, we&rsquoll see winds gradually swinging from the north, all the way from the Arctic pushing all that mild air way towards the south of us.&ldquoAnd we&rsquoll get this screaming northerly and if anything the wind could even turn a beastly north-easterly.&ldquoAround 4am that cold air is across Scotland, Northern Ireland and north of England.&ldquoStill relatively mild in the south there. Temperatures briefly might touch 10C or 11C in the south but we&rsquore mostly talking around 8C to 10C.&ldquoAnd then on Saturday a straight northerly blowing through bringing some showers to some of these eastern coasts turning increasingly wintery.The&nbspMet Office&nbspalso&nbsphas warned temperatures across Britain will plunge starting from Friday afternoon as Arctic weather embraces the country.BBC Weather forecast: Temperatures will plummet to single figures UK wide this weekend (Image: BBC)Forecaster Clare Nasir said thermometers will hit as low as -5C on Saturday morning, covering rural areas with ice and blanketing high grounds with&nbspsnow.The Met Office meteorologist said: Through the first part of Friday, this rain band clears Wales, the Midlands, eastern parts of England and clears down towards the southeast. Elsewhere lot of showers from the word-go, rain showers, hail along the coast but over the higher grounds risk of snow.Temperatures taking a tumble as that cold air filters in. Through Friday evening we continue to see those showers, a wintry mix and more persistent bursts coming in on the eastern side of England through the early hours of the morning.She continued: The countryside is going to have a very, very cold start to Saturday morning as temperatures dip down subzero, -3C to -5C so the risk of ice through the early hours of Saturday.A squeeze on the isobars as well, and organised bands of showers moving in from the North through the early hours of Saturday morning, with the risk of ice inland.According to the latest weather charts which analyse the probability of snowfall, Scotland is set to be hit by the white stuff during the early hours of Saturday morning.WeatherAction&rsquos Piers Corbyn said: &ldquoWe are expecting some quite severe snowfall before the end of this month and it will not just be confined to the far north, this could reach parts of the Midlands or even further south.&ldquoThis spell of very cold weather looks like bringing substantial snow to a more widespread area of the country than people would necessarily expect at this time of year.&ldquoWe are also forecasting some very low temperatures, we could see the record for October broken this year.

story: A massive 6.8 magnitude earthquake has struck off the coast of Greece  (Image: EMSC)The epicentre of the quake was located in the Ionian Sea, near the Greek Island of Zante and about 50 miles north-east of the city of Pyrgos.The quake had a depth of around 16 kilometres.The US Geological Survey (USGS) said casualties are possible.A witness said online: Me and my partner are staying in Zante, it woke my partner up, and we've had three aftershocks much smaller, the larger quake has moved several items around the room.&nbsp                Natural global warming led to TWO mass extinctions                Earthquake WARNING: Earth enters &lsquoCRITICAL&rsquo period for major tremorAnother witness described the tremors to the European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre (EMSC) saying there was extremely violent shaking.He added: Objects fell off shelves.Loud rumbling.According to reports, the quake lasted 15 to 30 seconds.The quake was located in the Ionian Sea, near the Greek Island of Zante  (Image: EMSC)Local media reported that a 15th century monastery in the Strofades area of the island has been damaged.Italy's Il Messaggero news site reported that the earthquake was felt as far as southern Italy.It claimed firefighters in the regions of Sicily, Calabria and Puglia received thousands of phone calls after the quake struck.According to the USGS, a local small tsunami is possible and residents have been advised to move away from the shores. title: make this budget philips last
story: Next Monday, on the eve of Halloween, Phil Hammond will raise the curtain on his latest tax-hiking non-Tory Budget.If there’s any justice, it will be his last.If Theresa May’s Downing Street days are numbered, so should those be of her Death Watch Chancellor.Together, they are the unrivalled stars of Tory MP Johnny Mercer’s glorious Whitehall farce, “The Sh*t Show”.Excitable critics say Mrs May is entering a “killing zone”.Rivals jockey for position while party chiefs try to streamline the timetable for picking her successor.This Prime Minister’s Number Ten tenancy is almost up. So is Hammond’s next door.Whoever takes over — Boris, David Davis or Jeremy Hunt — needs an emergency clear-out.The big guns of the Treasury need to be pointed at the “enemy” not its own side.After two long, wasted years, Britain is engaged in an unexpectedly desperate fight, not just to salvage Brexit but to save British democracy.Weekend crowds demanding a second referendum seem oblivious to the threat such a crazy re-run would pose to this nation’s centuries-old stability, ironically the envy of Europe.We cannot reverse the  referendum without turning Brexit into a perpetual running sore. And Britain can never rejoin the EU except on its knees.The only way to put this corrosive issue to bed is for Brexit to succeed — as it will, despite treacherous Tony Blair and Facebook hypocrite Nick Clegg.To succeed as we must we need a new chancellor as well as a new prime minister.Diehard Remainer Phil Hammond should be first out the door.It was Spreadsheet Phil who vetoed vital preparations for No Deal — now a better-than - prospect with time rapidly running out.And it was Hammond who surrendered the one negotiating weapon Brussels fears most — a thriving, low-tax Britain competing with the EU on its doorstep.Our economic fate is entirely in our hands. We can make taxes and tarfs as competitive as we like.Better investment incentives and lower corporation tax rates would trigger a flood of foreign investment in UK plc — and ensure car makers like Nissan and Toyota never leave our shores.Yet the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has ruled them out.“Phil is like those Harry Potter Dementor creatures,” says a top Tory. “He sucks the le out of any room he happens to be in.”Hammond is easily replaced. Michael Gove, an ex-future PM but a formidable Cabinet minister, has the drive and imagination to take on the Treasury “Blob”.There is no shortage of Brexit talent on the Tory benches.Just compare thundering Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC with prissy dried-stick predecessor Dominic Grieve.Grieve is busy sabotaging Brexit. Cox finds ways to make it work.He is now “marking Number Ten’s homework” on Mrs May’s wretched Northern Ireland “backstop”.Some even tip him as a dark horse in the leadership stakes.There is one other big change needed at the heart of Britain’s Brexit team.Our next PM must have a new EU negotiator.Nobody could be worse than Olly Robbins, already reportedly eyeing up a £m-a-year golden parachute into a top City job.Lelong Europhile Robbins has led Mrs May into so many disastrous EU traps — especially her humiliation in Salzburg — he is often cast as an EU “double agent”.It was Robbins who told EU negotiator Michel Barnier that Britain might stay indefinitely in “transition” while the fantasy Northern Ireland backstop was sorted out.And pay £bn more on top of the £bn ransom for the privilege.The idea that Robbins is the “EU’s man in Whitehall” is not such a stretch when you consider his Jeremy Corbyn-style applause for Communist Russia.Kremlin leaders, he told fellow Oxford students in , “changed Russia from a backward peasant autocracy, despised by the West, into a technological giant at whom the world cowered in fear for half a century.”Everyone is entitled to youthful naivety.But can anyone imagine Olly Robbins fighting our corner for EU democracy and accountability, let alone the referendum verdict of .m Brexit-voting Brits SAUDI Arabia’s rulers must be really annoyed with dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.This elderly trouble maker walked alone into his country’s Turkish consulate knowing he might never emerge alive.He was clearly looking for trouble.Once inside, using his bare hands, he attacked a gang of  innocent Saudi torturers who had just flown in for a couple of hours’ holiday armed only with a bone saw and a hypodermic syringe.Then, to the embarrassment of kindly Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, he went and hid his own body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teen asks how to burn cd
story: Before the days of streaming apps, music fans would assemble their favourite tracks onto CDs - a foreign concept to the younger generation these days.So when a teenager tweeted about the concept of CDs being burned it sparked a huge reaction.She wrote on Twitter: Maybe its just the generation Z in me but how did people burn CDs Like how did you just get a blank CD and put songs on it Thankfully one kind user explained the apparently ancient process.However most social media users took the opportunity to point out how old the tweet made them feel.One jokingly replied: All my hair turned grey reading this tweet.Another said: Part of me wants to explain how I used a blank cassette tape to record songs off the radio when I was a kid but I dont think Ill have time because theyve already lowered my casket into the hole and theyre shoveling dirt onto me at a truly frightening speed.A third user wrote: We would wait for a full moon and throw a blank CD into a giant bonfire and dance around it while chanting the titles of the songs we wanted on it.The final product would be sitting on top of the ashes after the flames went out.

title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. But it’s not just Harvey Weinstein and Hollywood.Over the past year, we’ve seen the High Court impose serious reporting restrictions on police arrests and a bid by Press-hating tycoon Max Mosley to wipe his fascist past out of history citing the ‘right to be forgotten’.It will be you, the public, who lose outthe rich and powerful stop us doing our job.GIVE us a date, Prime Minister.No, not for your departure. But for the end of the transition period.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond .If the PM has any hope of getting a deal through Parliament, the transition must have a legally-binding end date.Anything less would be the definition of a bad deal — and no deal is better than a bad deal.DOES John Bercow have no shame With every day he sits in the Speaker’s chair he discredits Parliament.His refusal to take allegations of bullying and harassment seriously is an embarrassment at the heart of our democracy.Parliament has a ready-made replacement for this rhino-hided oaf in Lindsay Hoyle — respected across the House.Bercow must go. Now.TURKISH supremo Recep Erdogan can spare us the holier than thou act on human rights.What happened to Jamal Khashoggi at the hands of the Saudis is disgraceful. But Erdogan’s record of political purges and locking up journalists is not far off.He has more in common with the regime in Riyadh than he’d like to think.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: photo ghost woman grave
story: Pauline Day said her teams electric energy meters were going haywire when the haunting pictures were taken at a graveyard in West Yorkshire.They show a mysterious mist forming in front of the camera as it takes a shape that resembles an older woman with her arm extended.Rob Crabtree, , took the snaps of the gravestone in Todmorden Unitarian Church.Rob, from Bradford, believes the final photo shows Sarah Agnes, who died aged  in  and is buried in the plot with her husband, James Davenport.He said: “We went out into the graveyard – it’s a real spooky place – and I took a few photos, and that’s one of the pictures that I caught.“If you read the gravestone there’s a lady buried there who was  and there’s also a lady that was , and I think it was her.“I just got a feeling that it was her and the face looked older.”He added: “Everybody can see it straight away that it’s a lady’s face. I’ve shown it to quite a few people and they’ve all made it out straight away.”Rob, who says the churchyard wasn’t even misty at the time, recalls feeling drawn to that particular headstone.“I was drawn to it definitely,” he said. “I took pictures of one or two other gravestones but that one I took quite a few of.“I did get the feeling I was in touch with someone.”Pauline Day, who organised the charitable ghost hunt, said she had sensed a spirit at the graveside.“I was calling out to her,” she said. “l could sense that she was there because our electric energy meters were going off.”“Then at break time – at am in the morning – we all went through our cameras to see what we had got and, to our surprise, one of my guests captured this picture.“We were all elated.”The church itself dates back to  and remained open until , though it is still licensed for weddings.

title: theresa may full scale no deal brexit plans
story: The Prime Minister will hit go on detailed emergency plans to get everyone ready for not securing an agreement in November, which would see current Commons business ditched.If theres not an agreement on the cards by then, ministers will be forced to put forward a series of new bills to get passed by March , when Britain officially leaves the EU.At least four are needed to guarantee the rights of EU citizens and on fishing beforehand.And thousands of bits of other laws have to be drafted too to make sure our laws are fit for purpose after we leave the bloc.Ministers have been deliberating for months when to push the go button on full-scale No Deal plans, The Times reported.Talks are still deadlocked with the EU over the Irish border, but both sides have said they are still hopeful a deal can be sealed.That will likely be signed off at Decembers EU Council meeting, but an emergency summit in Brussels could be called at any time, both sides have said.Today Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab told MPs in the Commons: We are striving for a good deal with our partners, but we will be ready for No Deal.He said there was a risk of failing to sign off an agreement, especiallythe EU engage in a deliberately transient approach.And he warned of the French deliberately directing a ‘go slow’ approach by supporting a ersion of the flow to more amenable ports in other countries.To get ready he said that , letters had been sent already to customs users, and , to businesses on how to prepare. technical notices have already been sent to get the country as ready as possible for whatever outcome.Chancellor Philip Hammond has set aside billions of pounds to for emergency plans.If the No Deal plans get put into action, , businesses will be told by Christmas they have to register for customs dutiesthey sell within the EU.And the Department of Health will be expected to sign contacts to stockpile medicines in case of any border disruption.One senior government figure told the paper that cabinet had decided that the government needed to “crack on”.We’re about to introduce no-deal legislation very, very soon,” they said.We have to crack on because it will all need royal assent before we leave. Then there will be an awful lot to discuss and it will concentrate minds. Obviously we don’t want to upset the negotiations but the clock is ticking and it will get harder and harder the later we leave it.PRO-EU party bosses are today lobbying Michel Barnier to try and convince him Brexit should be reversed.Leaders from the Lib Dems, Greens, SNP and Plaid Cymru have travelled to Brussels for a meeting with the EUs top Brexit envoy.They promised to push him to try and keep Britain in the single market and customs union - and make the case for a so-called peoples vote.Lib Dem chief Vince Cable said: “Our ‘unholy alliance’ has provided a sensible counterpoint to the hard-line Brexiteers who have pushed the Conservatives and Labour’s frontbench into senseless and fudged positions.It is vital that Michel Barnier and the European Commission know that there is another view in Parliament, one that has cross-party support and that can get the EU and the UK out of this mess.The SNPs Ian Blackford added: While the UK Government clearly still has no plan to break the Brexit impasse, and Labour fail to act as an effective opposition, it has been left to the unofficial opposition to speak up for a deal that would protect jobs and livelihoods.The Remainer politicians vowed to continue pushing Mr Barnier and other Eurocrats.But a damning report yesterday said that major projects getting our borders ready for No Deal might not be ready in time.The National Audit Office’s alarming investigation found the Government faces a race against time to replace critical IT systems, boost Border Force staffing levels and build new infrastructure to track goods in time for our departure next March.  out of  were at risk of not being done before we leave.It was revealed earlier this week that ministers will step up No Deal planning - with weekly updates to the cabinet.Mrs May told MPs that a deal was  per cent done, with the remaining five per cent focusing just on Northern Ireland issues.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gold leaf poppies remembrance day
story: One in six poppies will have “-” printed in gold on the green leaf.It is part of the organisation’s campaign to get people to buy and wear a poppy to pay their respects to those who sacriced their lives during the Great War.The Legion has launched its biggest poppy appeal to date, which is less than three weeks before Remembrance Sunday.The special gold leaf poppy isn’t the only addition to this year’s all-important campaign.Another poppy is also being launched today and it is even rarer than the gold leaf poppy.It is called the “khadi” poppy and instead of being made from paper is it made from the same linen that was worn by Mahatma Gandhi.Not many have been produced, about ,, and they have been made to honour the , Indian Army troops who lost their lives fighting for the Crown during World War I.The Legion launches their campaign today by also unveiling  installations across the UK to highlight the legacy of the Great War.The installations are a six-metre high poppy with red threads stretching across the floor featuring messages from the World War I generation and it is to highlight how their legacy is woven into the fabric of the UK.This year is especially important as this year’s Poppy Appeal wants to encourage people to highlight reasons to say “Thank You” to the Great War generation.The Royal British Legion’s Director of Fundraising, Claire Rowclfe said: “We thought it poignant in the year we mark the end of the First World War centenary to launch a special version of our paper poppy for the Poppy Appeal, something we have never done before.There are  million in the  million we distribute during the Remembrance period, and we look forward to seeing those who find one wearing their special poppy with pride.”Prime Minister Theresa May is set to help launch this year’s campaign.You can make a one-off donation online, set up a regular gt or even leave a sum in your will.You can donate by calling    or by sending a text message.To donate £, you can text POPPY to .Or to donate £, text POPPY to .You can also print off a donation form to send money in the post.The Legion hopes to raise £million this year.Poppies were first worn after American academic Monia Michael was inspired by Canadian medic Lt-Col John McCrae’s poem In Flanders Fields.In  she crafted and sold red silk poppies and the idea took off after coming to England.The first Poppy Appeal was held in , which was the founding year of The Royal British Legion.The poppy is a symbol of remembrance and hope and it is the colour red because of the flower’s natural colour.Some people wear a white poppy that is sold by the Peace Pledge Union as a symbol of peace and pacism and show their opposition to war.The Legion’s annual Poppy Appeal comes as Cambridge University Students’ Union tried to scrap the mention of poppies in the university’s plans for Remembrance Day.In an initial poll,  of  representatives voted to remove the mention of poppies and “British war veterans”.The motion was debated and eventually defeated.

title: dog pretended stray begged food outside mcdonalds
story: Betsy Reyes of Oklahoma City, USA says Princess sneaks out at night and lingers outside her local fast food restaurant in the hope customers will feed her.In a Facebook post that has since gone viral, Reyes shared a photo of Princess saying: “If you see my dog @ the McDonald’s on shields, quit feeding her fat ass bc she don’t know how to act  be leaving the house all the time to go walking to McDonald’s at night.“She’s not even a stray dog.”Reyes decided that sharing the image on Facebook was simply not enough, and drove to catch the pet in the act at her local McDonalds on Monday night, reported Time.She caught her dog waiting to bed fed by other customers. In the video, a woman in her car appears to throw Princess some food from the window.She posted the video, writing: “When I caught her ass in the act.”As she pulled up to the driveway, her dog immediately recognised her and started wagging her tail before jumping up and down in excitement.The hilarious posts racked up more than k likes on Facebook, and has over k comments.Many comments have labelled Princess as a “a”, while others called her “smart” and “funny”.The dog received some serious recognition, and even had a fan account made for her on Instagram called dogatmacdonald.Others took the opportunity to transform the original picture of Princess into a hilarious meme.

title: picture deer hiding forest
story: The colour of the little fawns coat blends perfectly with the background keeping it camouflaged and safe from predators.The little deer was unwittingly caught on camera by photograher Ingo Gerlach, , who failed to spot it as he was looking at two stags rutting in the distance.It was only later that his pictures revealed the hidden animal nestled close to a clump of tree stumps and fallen trees just feet away from him.Ingo said: The young stag really adapted well to his surroundings which is why he is so hard to spot.I couldnt believe it when I realised the young deer had been right in front of me.He must have been hiding from the older deer who can be quite aggressive when in rut.The young stag was snapped in front of a forest in the Sauerland region in Germany.The rut is a part of the mating season where male deer have a large increase in testosterone which leads them to be more aggressive and sometimes violent.

title: rogue landlords
story: His landlord was desperate to drive him out, and had switched off all the electricity to his Kensal Rise flat in north-west London, meaning hed been forced to live in the dark, causing the atrocious accident.Daud - who is blind in one eye and originally from Somalia -managed to crawl naked and bleeding onto the street, where a neighbour discovered him and called an ambulance.The -year-old spent  days in a West London hospital - four in the major trauma ward – with swelling to his spinal cord that caused numbness.The rogue landlord is just one of many operating in Britain today, but Dauds case highlights just how low some landlords will stoop to make their tenants lives hell.Things got even worse when Daud was discharged and found he had no home to go back to.His landlord sent him a brutal a message via family members, which said: “Tell that black bastard that I have evicted him and his s**t is outside.”When Daud ed to the dismal property he called home, the locks had been changed and his belongings removed from the flat where his unscrupulous landlord had been trying to force him out by disconnecting the electricity and removing the meter.I called my landlord, Bernard McGowan, to say I was outside my property and homeless. He laughed at me, Daud tells Sun Online.He later took McGowan to court and won damages, but his local council didn’t prosecute.“I will never forget that night as long as I live,” Daud says.“I went home at pm in a neck brace to find all my worldly possessions, including a ripped photo of my mum on her wedding day in Somalia, thrown into the street.“I had nowhere to go, and that night I felt suicidal. I saw no point in living.A friend offered him a temporary place to stay.Three years on, Daud, now , is proudly running his own community centre in Brent - All Nations - helping people from all ethnic backgrounds with problems such as the one he experienced. He also has a council property to call home.“That night changed my le and made me realise that I was going to have to start my le all over again. I love helping people and I am proud of the work I do.”Property owner Bernard McGowan boasts of having a £m portfolio but has been convicted six times since , and was fined more than £, for property offences last year.His tenants have complained of intimidation, electricity being disconnected, locks being changed and deposits never being ed - and of forced evictions from homes riddled with cold, damp and vermin, sometimes with beds and personal possessions strewn outside the front doors.Many of McGowan’s tenants are vulnerable. Erskine Clarke was sleeping rough before the council housed him in a West London property costing almost £ a week for a ft x ft room in a shared house with mould, a faulty boiler and a leaking toilet.Erskine says requests for repairs to McGowan were ignored, and the boiler problem went on for two years, resulting in no heating or hot water.He still lives at the property but now has a new landlord who is renovating it.The scarred tenant adds: “Nobody should be living in the state it was in. It made me depressed. I lost a lot of weight and got very sick. Why does the government let people do this But sadly, Doud and Erskine arent the only tenants suffering.Between  and , landlord Gary Fixter, , failed to act on repeated warnings to improve the standard of his properties, despite collecting £, a year in rent and earning a salary of £, a year as an IT consultant.He pleaded guilty to  offences between  and , with eight convictions for renting out substandard shared houses, often without heating, water supplies or fire alarms.He rented out a shed for £ a month, a property with live wires spilling out from the mains electrical unit, and another infested with rats.One of those hoping for justice for private rental tenants is -year-old Askel Douglas, who last year was spending every penny of his £ a week universal credit on a Neasden flat above a supermarket in London which flooded three times.“I was totally ripped off by my private landlord, Askel, who has now moved, told The Sun Online.There was water coming out of the walls and ceilings so it was knee-deep and a total mess, and stinking, dirty water was coming up through the plug so I couldn’t even have a bath.Jacky Peacock OBE, is director of London charity AdviceRenters, which is campaigning for reform of the private renting sector.She and her colleagues regularly witness the appalling standards in domestic renting which can be so bad they make tenants ill.“The things I see are atrocious. Filthy flats in a state of complete disrepair, but also we see many problems with overcrowding,” Jacky told The Sun Online.“People are exploited by employers as well as landlords, often migrant workers who are hardly paid anything, and they end up in these dreadful places, trying to raise their children.“We recently saw a Hungarian couple who lived with their six-year-old child in one small room. The husband was a mini cab driver who worked all hours to earn money for them, and he came back to the property one day to find the landlord had let himself into the room and was molesting his we.“The landlord brandished a kitchen kne and tried to stab the tenant – this is the kind of atrocious thing we’re seeing day after day.
