title: aussies-say-good-on-ya-to-melrosian-honesty
story: MELROSE isnrsquot just the best place to live in Scotland.It is also the most honest, according to two Australian tourists.The couple from Down Under were sampling the historical delights of the town recently.But Afton Johnston and her husbandrsquos dream trip turned into a nightmare when they left their camera, full of holiday memories, in Market Square.The couple had driven almost  miles north before realising.But, thanks to staff at a Melrose cafe, the Melbourne pair can enjoy leafing through their snaps once again.Afton told the Border : ldquoWe discovered later that I had left my camera on a seat in the square.ldquoAfter leaving the square I went shopping in Boots the chemist. And from Melrose we drove to Falkirk, where I discovered my camera containing a monthrsquos holiday photos was missing.ldquoAt the Falkirk Wheel Visitor Centre they made some calls for me. The chemist suggested that we ring the cafe in front of the seat. They rang Rhymers Fayre and the gentleman there went out into the street to check.ldquoMy camera was still on the seat after two hours, we drove to Melrose and collected it. Thank you to the helpful Melrose folk.The town was named the best place to live in Scotland, by the Sunday Times back in March.

title: scottish-wildcats-release-planned-for-scottish-borders
story: A CONSERVATION group has unveiled plans to reintroduce the Scottish wildcat into the Borders.The move by Wildcat Haven comes as proposals to release six lynx into Kielder are currently being considered by the UK Government.It is widely accepted that Scottish wildcat numbers have been dwindling across their native Highlands for many years.And Wildcat Haven has been spearheading fieldwork over the last decade to end the decline.This week the group announced its latest plans - to release the iconic felines along the Scotland-England border.Dr Paul ODonoghue, chief scientic advisor with Wildcat Haven, told us: "The British ecology needs a wildcat in it and wildcats fit in perfectly, helping to control species like rabbit and actively avoiding conflict with humans.ldquoThe Highlands cant afford to lose any Scottish wildcats so well be looking to healthy, wild-living European populations, and using them to re-establish a British wildcat population on both sides of the Scottish-English border.The proposals initially focus on the Galloway area with the reintroduced cats being encouraged to spread into the Scottish Borders as well as Cumbria and Northumberland.If the plans are successful it would be the first time wildcats have been present in England for over  years.Dr ODonoghue added: ldquoWeve seen that wildcats can really thrive in man-made forests, and an important part of our research is understanding how we can create a sustainable population in this environment."The Galloway-Northumberland border region is often overlooked but this is one of the most well connected and erse habitats in the UK, and certainly rivals the Highlands for bioersity potential."The wildcat is the UKs most endangered animal, and its probably the most charismatic and iconic species that has managed to cling on here against all odds theyre incredible survivors and I have no doubt they will thrive in the forests of the Southern Uplands and Northern England."The plan already has considerable landowner support coming from Gresham House Forestry, one of the largest owners of forestry in the UK and the Galloway region.Jason Sinden, Director of Forestry, said: "Gresham House manages almost , acres of forestry assets in the border region."These forests are managed to produce a sustainable supply of timber and this helps to create almost ideal habitats for a range of native woodland specialists, such a red squirrels, badgers and roe deer."The forests are now being re-colonised by pine-martens and we hope that the habitat can also be suitable for the wildcat, which is such an important component of forest eco-systems."We will be working with Wildcat Haven to identy appropriate sites for release and monitoring.

title: council-agrees-185m-plan-to-build-1000-affordable-homes
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has agreed a five year affordable housing plan which could see over , homes built by .Local authorities are required to submit affordable housing plans to the Scottish Government each year, which itself has a target of building , new homes.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive body on Tuesday, councillors were asked to give their approval to the plans by Cathie Fancy, the local authorityrsquos housing strategy and services manager.She told councillors: ldquoItrsquos really pertinent here, that over the last ten housing strategy submissions to the government, wersquove delivered about  new affordable homes, but over the next five years wersquore actually hoping to provide more than that.ldquoThis just shows you the extent of the ambition in what wersquore trying to do and and everyone is playing their part.The homes will represent nearly poundm of investment over a five year period, which will be funded by grants from the Scottish Government, private borrowing from housing associations and money raised by Scottish Borders Councilrsquos second homes tax.Councillor Mark Rowley, the local authorityrsquos executive member for business and economic development, said: ldquoConsidering we donrsquot hold housing stock ourselves, itrsquos a great tribute to Cathy that housing has been such a priority for this council, and I know that the many people living in wonderful homes across the Scottish Borders will be very grateful to her.,params: .pushldquoThese figures are quite incredible. In rough terms, wersquore talking about an investment here of around poundm between ious sources, including ourselves, our partners and government.ldquoA lot has been raised by quite spirited borrowing from our registered social landlord partners who, like the council, are being very ambitious about housing in the Scottish Borders.ldquoIf we can deliver an extra , good, affordable, warm homes then that is to be commended.ldquoThe overall message here is incredibly positive, itrsquos talking about building homes across the region and building them in a signicant quantity.Kelso councillor Simon Mountford also welcomed the report, heaping praise on the environmentally friendly plans for energy-efficient housing: ldquoOne thing I would like to highlight from the presentation is the plan from Eildon Housing Association to build a number of passive houses.ldquoThey will dramatically reduce the cost of heating for the tenants of those housing. When we consider that fuel poverty is one of those things that we as a council very much want to tackle then this is a step in the right direction.ldquoI personally hope that this will be a switch to building passive houses as standard throughout the Borders.Speaking after the meeting, Mid Berwickshire councillor Mr Rowley added: ldquoAs a council we are determined to support the delivery of much-needed affordable homes across the area.ldquoThis helps young people stay and work in the area, have families and put down roots here. That has a signicant, long term positive impact on our local economy.ldquoMore than , affordable homes would go a long way to meeting housing needs in our communities over the next five years and would also help support the local construction sector, providing a further boost to the economy.ldquoIt is an ambitious plan and there are certainly some challenges, from land supply to funding, but we continue to work very closely with a range of partners, including registered social landlords and the Scottish Government, to maximise opportunities to deliver more affordable homes.

title: unemployment-soars-in-the-scottish-borders
story: UNEMPLOYMENT in the Borders has soared by almost  per cent from last year.Figures released by the Department for Work and Pensions show a surge of benefits claimants in the past  months from  last September to a current figure of .The unemployment increase is across all age demographics, with a -person riserecorded in -to- year-olds.Although the year-on-year increase of  percent is disappointing, staff at local Jobcentres highlighted a long-term trend which has seen  percent reduction in claimants across the Borders since .Staff at Galashiels Jobcentre are also launching several courses in a bid to help more people back into work.Customer Services Leader Stephen Glen told us: "We are currently running a Construction SBWA for customers in Galashiels Jobcentre Plus for our unemployed customers keen to work in the Construction Industry."It will provide the  participants with an opportunity to gain the necessary certication to work in construction."Funding has been applied for to run two -plus courses in the Gala area aimed at supporting our longer term unemployed customers aged  and over."These courses will be ready to start once a suitable provider in the area has been sourced."

title: st-boswells-store-in-the-running-to-become-britains-best-small-shop
story: A COMBINED bookshop, cafeacute, deli and homeware shop in St Boswells is in the running to become Britainrsquos Best Small Shop of .The Mainstreet Trading Company, which is celebrating its tenth anniversary this year, is one of  independent retailers from across the country named on the prestigious shortlist.Over the years, innovations introduced by the business include the lsquoA Year of Booksrsquo subscription service, Book Burrows for children and the Love Your Indie book loyalty card.Rosamund de la Hey, co-owner of Mainstreet, told us: "We are always looking for ways to engage with the local community."Whether thatrsquos through our Bookshop Van, which aims to ensure every child in the Borders meets an author through Mainstreet during their school le through our Summer Reading Diary where children review up to six books with the winners receiving their height in books or our noticeboard to publicise local arts events.The Best Small Shops competition, which is managed by the Independent Retailers Confederation sponsored by loyalty app booost, celebrates the commitment and creativity of independent retailers on the UKrsquos High Streets and the central role they play in their local communities.Mark Walmsley, chairman of the Independent Retailers Confederation, added: "Despite all of the bad headlines and the high-profile closures of larger stores, we firmly believe that specialist independent retailers can thrive in this climate by delivering a truly unique retail experience.ldquoThe Best Small Shops competition enables us celebrate this unique industry, the passion, service, flexibility and knowledge of independent shop owners offer and show customers what makes independent retailers so special.The winner of Britainrsquos Best Small Shop will be announced at an event at the Houses of Parliament on November .

title: great-adventurers-brought-to-book-by-jo
story: OVER the past few years, Royal Scottish Geographical Society writer-in-residence Jo Woolf has immersed herself in the Societyrsquos archives.So much so, that last year she published her debut book The Great Horizon, which features  exceptional adventure stories from the last  years - and each from an inidual connected to the Society.From missionaries and mavericks to visionaries and voyagers, the explorers included in Jorsquos book have ventured into unknown regions of the globe ndash across ice, desert, and rainforest, over uncharted waters, and into the unfathomed depths of the ocean.Some are famous historical characters, such as Sir Ernest Shackleton, Roald Amundson, Sir Edmund Hilary and Neil Armstrong.But there is also an intriguing collection of additional names such as Isobel Wylie Hutchison, Hubert Wilkins, Marion Newbigin and Mildred Cable that are less well known that Jo skilfully shines a light on.As part of the RSGS Inspiring People talks programme, Jo will be bringing to le some of these characters and their stories in a richly illustrated presentation and QA session entitled Beyond the Horizon.The event will take place at .pm on Tuesday October in Galashiels.Speaking about her upcoming talk, Jo Woolf said: "I have been repeatedly amazed, moved, entertained, and uplted by these remarkable stories."The definition of exploration may have been re-shaped somewhat over the decades, but the courage and enduring spirit of explorers is still the same. "Having spent the last few years digging around in the archives of the RSGS, I want to share some of these extraordinary tales with you, and tell you how I came to write The Great Horizon.Jorsquos talk will take place on Tuesday at .pm at the Scottish Borders Campus, Nether Road, Galashiels, TD HE.Ticketswill be available on the door or online via Eventbrite until noon the day before.

title: home-bargains-submits-plans-for-hawick-homebase-site
story: THE Homebase store in Hawick could be given a new lease of le as a rival retailer has submitted plans for the site to Scottish Borders Council.The parent company of discount retail giant Home Bargains, TJ Morris, has put in an application to the local authorityrsquos planning department to allow food retailing on the premises.The Liverpool-headquartered firm has stores at  locations and currently employs around , staff throughout the UK.It also opened up a new poundm store in Galashiels in the summer, providing dozens of new jobs in a ,sq ft unit in Stirling Street.Homebase, on the other hand, announced in August that it was closing  of its stores, putting , staff out of work, as part of a national shake-up designed to revive its fortunes.That includes its store at Galalaw Retail Park in Hawick at the cost of  jobs.Speaking at the time the closure was announced, Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk MP John Lamont said: ldquoThis is hugely disappointing news for staff, their families and Hawick itself.ldquoJust when it seems that a recovery is on the horizon for the town, a blow like this is announced.ldquoHomebase have promised to relocate staff where possible. However, with the next nearest stores being in Carlisle or Berwick, this isnrsquot going to be suitable for most.The application from TJ Morris, submitted by Glasgow-based planning consultancy Iceni Projects, would see  per cent of the ,sq m site given over to food retailing, although the company is refusing to comment on the specics of the proposal.Hawick and Denholm councillor Stuart Marshall has welcomed the news, saying: ldquoI think itrsquos very encouraging that someone has come along so quickly.ldquoI know the company were expressing great interest, and Irsquom sure many people will be pleased by this news.The application might provide similar jobs at the site, but the presence of another out-of-town retailer will do little to revitalise the high street of a town which has been in dramatic decline over the last decade.A recent report put to Scottish Borders Council showed that footfall in the town centre has more than halved since , and there are now  retail units standing vacant.

title: light-therapy-arrives-at-bgh-via-the-fairways
story: FAIRYWAY-hitting golfers are helping to bring some light relief to Borders General Hospital.Dozens of big-hitters teed up at the Roxburghe Golf Course for the inaugural Friends of the BGH tournament, organised by Nigel Brown.Coming out on top of the leaderboard was the Middlemiss Embroidery Ltd team.But, undoubtedly, the overall winner is the hospitals dermatology department which will benefit from a new pound, PUVA light therapy machine - after more than pound, was raised for the pot during the tournament.James Marjoribanks from Friends of the BGH told us: "The PUVA Light Therapy machine, among other uses, can be used to treat skin cancer."We are the only health board in Scotland not to have one and Border patients who require this treatment have to travel up to Edinburgh at the moment, so we are really grateful to all the teams that took part, the sponsors, Roxburghe Golf Club and, especially Nigel Brown for organising this event.If anyone is interested in raising additional money for the Friends of the BGH, contact James at jym@hoggandthorburn.

title: matt-leaves-behind-the-whale-to-play-in-the-borders
story: FOUNDING member of Noah and the Whale, Matt Owens, is set to play in the Borders next month.And tickets are freeordered in advance.Noah and the Whale were among the pioneers of the indi-folk sound in the noughties along with the likes of Mumford and Sons and Vampire Weekend.Singles such as LIFEGOESON and  Years Time propelled them into the charts and onto the main stage at festivals across the world.After coming to prominence more than a decade ago as part of the of Noah and the Whale, Matt also went on to front the equally impressive Little Mammoths.And now, after penning a string of hits along the way, he is about to tour with his debut solo album Whiskey and Orchids, which he has been working on with Thea Gilmore, Michael Blair, Robert Vincentand Carleigh Aitkens.Matt will be joined at the Memorial Hall in Innerleithen by Nigel Stonier.Nigel is a producer, multi-instrumentalist and singer songwriter co-writer and since the s he has worked with a range of artists including Thea Gilmore, The Waterboys, Joan Baez, Martha Wainwright and Fairport Convention.Between  and  he has produced a total - for ious artistes - of  tracks playlisted on BBC Radio  and BBC Radio  Music.Since scoring a publishing contract when aged  Nigel has been an active and busy musician, initially attracting national radio attention with the band Northern Sky then setting his stall out as a producer collaborator.Ticketsfor the Matt Owens and Nigel Stonier concert in Innerleithen are free by registering in advance at www.onthebrinck events matt-owens-noah-and-the-whale-little-mammothsDoors open on Saturday, November  at pm.

title: tickets-now-on-sale-for-galashiels-remembrance-concert
story: AHEAD Of this years centenary of Armistice a special Remembrance Concertis being staged in Galashiels.Musicians, singers and poets will take to the Volunteer Hall stage to pay tribute to the sacrice made by so many in the four years of war up to .The show is part of the Gala Remembers  project which aims to highlight the towns war effort.And to create a respectful commemoration for all the  sons of Galashiels who didnt come home.Gordon Keddie is the organiser of the concert.He said: ldquoI discussed this idea with Energise Galashiels Trust and we agreed it was important to hold this event on the th anniversary of the ending of the First World War to give a proper tribute to the  men from Galashiels who lost their lives during the conflict.Among those to perform on the evening are Galashiels Ex-Service Pipe Band and the Town Band.Langlee Community Choir, One Acchord Choir, Alastair Waddell and Lorraine Kemp will also take to the stage.And there will be poetry by Galashiels Academy pupil Sophie MacDonald.Bill White, Chair of Gala Remembers  added: ldquoMusic halls were hugely popular during World War I and it is fitting we will have our own concert as part of Gala Remembers .ldquoThere is some great local talent set to perform on and we would encourage Borderers and visitors from further afield to come along to support them on this poignant and important weekend.The concert will take place on Friday, November  from .pm.Ticketsfor the show, priced at pound and include a souvenir programme, are on sale daily between pm and pm from the British Legion Club in Park Street, Galashiels.More information on Gala Remembers  is available at www.energisegalashiels gala-remembers-Notes to EditorsPhoto credit. title: belfasts-andy-set-to-rave-on-in-the-borders
story: ANDY White, Belfast born and Belfast bred, first picked up a guitar when he was .It was blocking up the hallway, so he started strumming it in a beatnik basement belonging to a big bloke called Bobby.So started the  press release for Andyrsquos debut album, reissued by Vinyl  on October .The eighties folk revival led by The Pogues, The Waterboys and Hothouse Flowers cut an authentic, soulful swathe through the music culture of the MTV generation.On Rave On, Andyrsquos voice and lyrics told the story of a boy growing up in the political and social chaos of Northern Ireland and making his way to Thatcherrsquos Britain with an acoustic guitar and a suitcase full of poetry books, Clash cassettes and Bob Dylan albums.Originally recorded in a field in County Antrim, this yearrsquos reissue is a limited edition in white g vinyl with a gatefold sleeve.It still sounds fresh, raw and urgent today and is complemented by latest album The Guilty  The Innocent, Andyrsquos reaction tothe current news cycle.Grenfell, Trump, Corbyn, equality and justice are its themes.The six minute title track stunned audiences on his UK tour last year.Along the line connecting these two albums, Andy has collaborated with the likes of Tim Finn and Liam O Maonlai , written with Peter Gabriel, recorded with Sinead OrsquoConnor and toured with Van Morrison.But Andyrsquos voice, trademark lyrical wit and the magic he can conjure up with musicians in a studio remains a constant.Along with a stellar career in music hersquos always kept a firm grip on the ldquohave guitar, will travel folksinger ethos on display in the back of a Beetle, one West London afternoon in .Andy will be touring across the UK this winter - including a date in the Borders.He will play at the Heart Of Hawick on Monday, December .Ticketsare avialable from  .

title: a-fairtrade-coffee-morning-for-melrose
story: MELROSE Rotarians have teamed up with the local Fairtrade Group to host a special coffee morning.Held later this month, the event will serve up Fairtrade tea, coffee and traybakes.And there will also be a chance to buy Christmas gts, decorations and a range of books to support the charity Kabuki UK.Peter Carter from the Rotary Club said: "As a key local charity, we feel it is important to recognise that Melrose is a Fairtrade Town. By making our coffee morning a Fairtrade event, not only are we raising funds for our own local work but we are also supporting farmers and growers in developing countries. Last year we welcomed over  people to our coffee morning and provided an excellent opportunity to socialise and take a break from Saturday morning shopping."The event is also being supported by the local Co-op store.The Fairtrade Group achieved Fairtrade Town status for Melrose in  and will be seeking to renew that position when members apply to the Fairtrade Foundation later this month.David Potts from the group added: "We have built a great partnership with the local Rotarians over the past two years and this will benefit us when we are called to show that the work of our group has grown and developed since our last renewal application.The coffee morning is being held at the Corn Exchange, on Saturday, October  from am until noon. Entry is free with tea, coffee and cake at pound.

title: chance-to-find-out-more-about-solar
story: BORDERERS will be able to find out more about solar renewable energy next week.Hosted by Change Works, a free information evening will be held in the Burgh Hall on Thursday for locals, businesses and community groups.From .pm, attendees will have an opportunity to chat to local specialist installers before hearing from Home Energy Scotland experts about the benefits of solar , the costs and savings involved and the free, impartial support which is available.A Resource Efficient Scotland advisor will also be on hand to provide advice and support to local Tweeddale businesses.Donna Marshall, Change Works in Peebles project manager told us: "This is an ideal event for any local householder, business or community group who has considered installing solar  or renewables and needs further advice to help make a decision."Solar photo voltaics can be a great way to cut your electricity bills."Sunlight is free, so once youve paid for the initial installation, your electricity costs can be reduced."Change Works in Peebles is here to help and support the local community to find out more about generating solar renewable energy."You can book your free place online at bit.ly SolarTweeddale pop into the Change Works in Peebles hub email peebles@changeworks.org.uk or call  .

title: funding-boost-is-a-path-to-success-on-the-eildons
story: PATHS on the Eildon Hills are set for improvement following a six-figure cash boost.The pound, funding, secured by Scottish Borders Council, will be used to improve areas of erosion on more than km of upland paths in the popular National Scenic Area.Councillor Mark Rowley, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for business and economic development, said: ldquoThe walks in the Eildons are extremely popular, not only with local people but also with visitors, as the paths include the well-known, long-distance route St Cuthbertrsquos Way.ldquoIt is estimated that around  walkers a week use these paths and it is vital to ensure that the experience for visitors is positive, due the impact on the local visitor economy, but also that the hills themselves and the paths are protected for future generations of Borderers and visitors to enjoy.The funding has been secured from the Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund, administered by VisitScotland.Announced last year by the Scottish Government, the fund aims to provide sustainable infrastructure projects that focus on improving visitor experience and enable more visitors to enjoy Scotlandrsquos rural communities.It was set up to address the pressure on infrastructure and negative impacts on local communities caused by the increasing popularity of Scotlandrsquos outstanding scenic areas.VisitScotland regional leadership director, Paula Ward, said: ldquoDue to the continued success of tourism it is crucial that we address those pinch points already identied and future-proof those areas where demand is growing.ldquoI am delighted that the Eildon Hills project will receive funding from the Scottish Government Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund to help enhance and safeguard this iconic part of the Scottish Borders scenery for future visitors and the local community.ldquoWith its proximity to the Borders Railway, it is popular with local walkers as well as those from further afield wishing to discover one of the best walks in the UK, and experience the fantastic scenery on offer at the top.ldquoVisitScotland, along with other agencies and industry partners, needs to encourage the tourism industry to provide world class service, facilities, events and attractions to keep up with ever-changing consumer demands and ensure visitors continue to have memorable experiences.The erosion of parts of the path network in the Eildons has been caused by ious factors, including weather, volume of use, soil type and topography.The councilrsquos Ranger Service manages maintenance on the promoted path routes over the hills, and over the past  years, has carried out a range of works on lower reaches of the paths.This latest project, to be carried out next year, will involve more intense upland path works.The Eildon Hills are owned by Buccleuch Estates. Edward Morris, estate manager at Buccleuchrsquos Borders Estate, said: ldquoAccess to the Eildon Hills is hugely valued by those who live in the region as well as visitors from across the country.ldquoIt is excellent news that the well-trekked path network is to be upgraded and this will only enhance the enjoyment of current enthusiasts and encourage new walkers to go out and enjoy this beautul landscape.

title: contestants-came-saw-and-conkered
story: THERE were some tough nuts to crack at the annual Scottish Conker Championships at the weekend.Competitors from all over the UK gathered on the Tweed Green in Peebles on Saturday ndash in a bid to take home one of the coveted trophies.And after taking part in a string of events, this yearrsquos winner was lsquoEl Conkistadorrsquo, from Conkistan, who defeated Norfolkrsquos Tim Frost in the final.Maurice Hurrell from Fe won the rogue category Tristan Van claimed the youth - trophy while Phoenix Taylor prevailed in the seven- age group.The event is organised each year by the Borders Forest Trust. And the organisation is delighted with how the day went.Anna Craigen, the grouprsquos community and education officer, told us: ldquoIt was a really good day by all accounts, everyone enjoyed it and we saw some new champions. We were very pleased for El Conkistador, who won the adult section, as he has been a regular competitor at the event for many years.ldquoWe were also very pleased with the turnout and luckily the weather held out for us ndash evenit did get a little bit chilly later on in the day.ldquoThere were four contestants taking part in the youth section,  in the adult section and  children taking part in the junior section, which was great.ldquoIt was also great to welcome many competitors from around Britain. We had some from Fe, and one contestant was from Norfolk, Tim Frost, who reached the final ndash that was the furthest distance travelled.

title: mr-mrs-success-for-bgh-baby-unit

title: community-rallies-to-produce-cascade-of-hand-knitted-tributes
story: AN eye-catching cascade of over , hand-knitted poppies has been draped from a Selkirk church in the run up to this yearrsquos centenary commemorations of Armistice.What began as a small-scale community project in February ndash with the aim of producing a woollen poppy for each of the townrsquos  soldiers who died in the Great War ndash soon spiralled into a major achievement with more than  knitters picking up their needles.And on Friday many of the volunteer knitters as well as the  or so who tied the poppies onto military netting witnessed the cascade being hung from the Parish Church steeple.David Deacon, coordinator of the Selkirk Remembrance project, is delighted with the community response to his initial poppy appeal.He said: ldquoOur aim to begin with was to get  poppies or maybe even  for each of the soldiers who went off to war.ldquoWe exceeded that, so we thought lsquowell, letrsquos try and get one for every man, woman and child in Selkirkrsquo which is about , to , people.ldquoAnd we soon exceeded that, wersquove just gone past the , mark, which now represents one for every person in the entire parish of Selkirk.ldquoAs a community, itrsquos been fantastic because people have gotten little groups together - some have even used it for rehab and recovery from hospital operations.A total of  young men left Selkirk to fight for their country on the battlefields of Europe and beyond during the - conflict.Only  of them came home.The symbolism and signicance of the cascade at the Church, as well as a smaller tribute of knitted poppies hung from the town-centre Pant Well, isnrsquot lost on Mr Deacon.He added: ldquoThis Parish Church is probably where a lot of the young men who went off to war would have come in the days before they left.ldquoThe Pant Well is also signicant as they would have left Selkirk from that very spot to go onto training and then onto the Front.ldquoWe are commemorating the th anniversary of the end of First World War ndash and I feel Selkirk is doing this as a community.The appeal for knitters was first made back in February with the world-famous Selkirk Yarnstormers, under the guidance of Kay Ross, taking up the challenge.Joining the  or so Yarnstormers were a further  or  volunteers who spent much of the summer producing the eye-catching red poppies.Several white poppies, in remembrance of the conscientious objectors, were also produced.Over the past two weekends the poppies were tied to military netting within the Parish Church hall by around  volunteers.Kay Ross told us: ldquoThis has been a magnicent achievement by so many people and it is a fitting tribute to the people who went off to war.Joining Mr Deacon on Friday to help with the draping of the cascade was a fellow former soldier Sandy Monks.And four of the townrsquos retained firefighters were also on hand to prevent any snags.Organisers are planning further commemorations in the run up to Remembrance on Sunday, November .As well as a unique parade from the Parish Church to the War Memorial on the Sunday morning, which will include the flag-bearers from all Selkirkrsquos casting societies, the Town Hall will be illuminated with red lighting.

title: recycled-remembrance-brings-a-tear-to-galashiels
story: A RECYCLING project with a dference has helped set the tone in Galashiels ahead of this years centenary commemorations of Armistice.Hundreds of plastic bottles were collected over the past year.And they have been turned into a stunning Poppy Teardrop display which was installed on the towns War Memorial at the weekend.The fitting tribute to the  men from Galashiels who made the ultimate sacrice during the - conflict was created by Jenni Golder from Paper Violet.Jenni, along with members of the Energise Galashiels Trust and other volunteers, collected and washed the bottles before they were cut into shape.The final recycled artwork, which was completed in July, contains over , poppies.Bill White, chairman of the Gala Remembers  project, told us: ldquoThis has been a fantastic project which not only provides a unique and special memorial to those who died during the Great War, but also re-uses plastics at a time when the impact of the material on the environment is a huge issue across the globe."A real community effort was needed to collect all the plastic bottles required by Jenni to take the final design, which has impressed all those who have seen it so far."We hope it inspires people to remember their past, as well as look to the future and the positive impact we can have on the environment.Artist Jenni used the base and top from each bottle to make the striking poppies.After being painted red, the designs were drilled and fixed to a cascade to create the Poppy Teardrop.Among the many who have visited the Poppy Teardrop since its installation is local councillor Gordon Edgar.The local authoritys energy efficiency champion, said: ldquoIt is great to see Jenni Golder and her team of volunteers play their part by reusing plastic bottles which otherwise could have affected our local environment.ldquoFor the material to then be used for such a worthwhile project is fantastic and it should encourage the reduce, reuse, recycle message we want to get across.Also being erected around Galashiels in the run up to the th anniversary of the Great War ending are commemorative banners.Pupils at Galashiels Academy helped design the striking images which have been strung from poles around the town centre.-year-old Finn Murray was among the designers.He said: "Our art class did research into Remembrance Day."I found images and photos which inspired me before I started work on my design."I was amazed that my design was chosen to go on public display.A total of  designs were chosen for display.Mr White added: "The banners designed by the the local secondary school children were of an extremely high standard."They were all winners, however only  could be selected for the final banners displayed in the town and it was a very dficult task for the judges to select the winners."They should all be very proud of their work.Gala Remembers  is a partnership of community groups and organisations working together to create a respectful commemoration for all those who served our country during WWI.

title: man-accused-of-causing-disturbance-at-galashiels-pub
story: A -year-old man has appeared from custody at Selkirk Sherf Court accused of causing a disturbancein a Galashiels public house at the weekend.Simon Hadden is charged with struggling violently with three police constables at the Bridge Inn on Saturday and striking a constable in the face.He is also said to have behaved in a threatening or abusive manner in the Bridge Inn, in a police vehicle en-route to Hawick Police Station and at the accident and emergency department of Borders General Hospital.Hadden faces a fourth charge of attempting to punch an officer at hawick Police Station.He pleaded not guilty to all four charges and a trial date was fixed for January  at Selkirk Sherf Court with an intermediate hearing on December .Hadden was released on bail with the special conditions not to enter the Bridge Inn or consume alcohol and must provide police with a breath sample of required.He was also placed on curfew at his home in Hawthorn Road, Galashiels, between the hours of pmand am.

title: borders-pupils-have-the-healthiest-smiles-according-to-latest-figures
story: FIGURES have shown that Borders primary one pupils have the best teeth in mainland Scotland.Dentists carried out inspections at all primary schools in the country during  .And they found that more than  percent of the  four-and five-year-olds inspected locally had no signs of decay.The figure is well above the national average of  percent and only beaten by schools in the islands.Of all the Borders primary one pupils inspected only . percent had letters sent home recommending immediate care due to decay or abscesses - again well below the national average of over seven percent.Primary  pupils in the Borders also have some of the healthiest smiles in the country.Of the  inspections carried out in Borders schools, only . percent of them were sent letters due to decay and abscesses.

title: cranston-fiddle-performance-in-selkirk
story: A TRAGEDY of one familys loss during the Great War will be retold tomorrow in Selkirk.The Cranston Fiddle is the true heart-breaking, yet ultimately uplting, story of a mother who lost her sons during World War I.And the drama is played out on the familys surviving fiddle - which is now owned and played by Sheila Sapkota from Selkirk-based Riddell Fiddles.TomorrowSheila and the rest of the Riddell Fiddles will perform a free open rehearsal of the multi-media play at the County Hotel ahead of their performance during Remembrance Sunday in Haddington.The production features musical pieces composed by Donald Knox especially for the project, slides presented by local photographer Ian Oliver and text and narration from Haddington-based author and historian Bob Mitchell.Tomorrows performance, which starts at pm, is free.

title: united-front-in-the-bid-to-extend-the-borders-railway
story: POLITICIANS have joined campaigners to show a united front in the bid to take trains all the way from Tweedbank to Carlisle.Grassroots group Campaign for Borders Railheld their th AGM in Hawick at the weekend.Around  people turned out for the meeting at Hawick High School on Saturday where a ldquoquestion time session saw a  face questions on plans for the future of the railway.Included in the  was John Lamont MP, Paul Wheelhouse MSP, academic Brian Eaton, leader of the Scottish Borders Council Shona Haslam Carlisle MP John Stevenson and former chair of the Friends of the Carlisle and Settle Line, Richard Morris.And the consensus from the stage was for the extension of the Borders Railway to be progressed as soon as possible.CBR chairman Simon Walton, who hosted the public event, said: ldquoWe invited lists from all facets of political and civic le to join us at our nineteenth annual general meeting, and they were able to demonstrate that whatever ideological dferences they may have, they were in no conflict over the benefits of being part of the national rail network.ldquoThat politicians demonstrated they are united behind the project, proves how far wersquove come.The meeting also heard that the Scottish Government had decided to take forward two rail-based proposals from the recent Borders Transport Corridors Study, identying Tweedbank to Carlisle as an option for exploration, as well as noting a possible link to the East Coast Main Line.Simon continued: ldquoThe Campaign remains committed to the re-establishment of the former lsquoWaverley Routersquo as the best and most achievable outcome.ldquoThe bottom line is that a new rail service through Hawick and the Scottish Borders will go a long way towards solving many of the economic and social challenges faced by the region.ldquoIt will be the most tangible and achievable way to kick-start that regeneration process, and bring about the beston investment for the benefit of the widest possible cross-section of the community.At the event, list and academic Brian Eaton gave examples of sparsely populated areas generating larger than expected traffic flow due to the availability of rail services. He gave the example of National Park station in New Zealand which, despite a low resident population, is among the busiest places on the North Island due to its accessibility by train.Shona Haslam, leader of Scottish Borders Council, emphasised the collateral benefits to communities around the Borders of having closer proximity to rail services.Richard Morris, the former chair of the Friends of the Carlisle and Settle Line, recounted how that Borders line had helped support enterprise in the rural economy.John Stevenson, the Carlisle MP, and ldquochampion of the Borderlands Growth Initiative reiterated his support for funding of a full feasibility study.Simon said: ldquoHaving the stated support of the new cross-border agency is a vital step forward. The Campaign and its members must take credit for pushing that agenda forward.ldquoJohn Stevenson did all but pull out his agencyrsquos cheque book, and Paul Wheelhouse reminded us that, while the current agenda puts extension several years down the road, itrsquos up to the Campaign to be ready to present the case for the Borders Railway extension in the eventually of circumstances changing.ldquoOur policy of informed and rational advocacy has served us well thus far and will serve the Borders well in the future. Wersquore closer now than ever to seeing everyonersquos ambition achieved.

title: galashiels-royal-british-legion-club-withdraws-remembrance-day-licensing-application
story: THE Royal British Legion Scotland club in Galashiels has withdrawn its application to open its bar early on Remembrance Sunday after council officers objected to those plans.The club organises the annual parade through Galashiels, as part of the Gala Remembers celebrations, drawing hundreds of marchers from both military and civilian backgrounds.However, this year the parade is set to go ahead earlier in the day, so licence holder John Ballantyne put in a request to Scottish Borders Councilrsquos licensing department for consent to sell alcohol from am on Sunday, November .Licensing officers objected to that application, saying that those extended opening hours would be against council policy.An objection letter written by licensing standards officer Ian Tunnah says: ldquoThe hours applied for are outwith the licensing boardrsquos current policy.ldquoThe licensing board policy states that the board will not normally grant applications for more than  hours in any -hour period. To grant the application would create a trading period for on-sales of  hours on the date applied for.ldquoIt may be considered more appropriate on this occasion to offer non-alcoholic refreshments prior to the solemn processions and ceremonies that follow.ldquoThere will no doubt be the customary gathering at the premises after the parades and ceremonies when alcohol will be available.ldquoIn my opinion,the application was to be granted it would be contrary to the licensing objective of protecting and improving public health.The application was due to be heard by Scottish Borders Councilrsquos licensing board on Friday, October , but has now been withdrawn.

title: nursery-cruelty-trial-is-adjourned-until-2019
story: THE trial of two nursery workers accused of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner towards children in their care has been put off until next year at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Nicola Jeffrey, who is , and -year-old Teresa Renton are alleged to have committed the offence on several occasions on ious occasions between January , , and August , .It is said to have happened at Little Reivers Nursery in Duns, which has since closed.They have both pleaded not guilty to a charge of shouting, forcibly dragging children about and lting them off the floor by the arm, locking children inside cupboards and refusing to let them out when they became disorientated.They are also accused of making offensive and abusive comments towards and about young children and behave in an aggressive, threatening and abusive manner towards youngsters in their care.Jeffrey is further alleged to have seized hold of the arm of an injured child who was receiving treatment from a colleague and it was later ascertained the arm had sustained two fractures.Jeffrey is also said to changed the nappy of a child in a public place in view of the public on a concrete floor without using any mat.Renton of Ainslie Terrace and Jeffrey of Rachel Drive, both Duns, pleaded not guilty to the charge.The trial was scheduled to get underway thismorning but has been adjourned until January  after the defence requested more time for preparations.

title: ballantynes-two-child-cap-defence-causes-storm-in-holyrood
story: A BORDERS MSP has caused a storm at Holyrood after attempting to defend the controversial two-child cap on claiming tax credits.Michelle Ballantyne, who is a former Selkirkshire councillor and leader of the local Conservatives, was defending welfare reforms during the session at the Scottish Parliament yesterday .Universal Credit was introduced as part of the UK Governments overhaul of the welfare system.Critics say cuts to payments and widespread problems with its implementation have led to many people falling into hardship or dropping out of the benefit system altogether.The introduction of the two-child benefit cap, limiting tax credits and Universal Credit to a familys first two children has also been attacked.And the Tory list MSPs attempt to justy the two-child cap this week was met with anger and disbelief.Ms Ballantyne told Holyrood: "The two-child limit is about fairness."It is fair that people on benefit cannot have as many children as they like while people who work and pay their way and dont claim benefits have to make decisions about the number of children they can have."Universal Credit may have its flaws, but the thinking behind the system is sound."It is about making it better to be in work than not to be in work."MSPs were debating inequality, austerity and poverty when Ms Ballantyne mounted her defence.Nationalist MSP Tom Arthur described her words as one of the most disgraceful speeches Ive ever heard.He said: "In my two and half years in this parliament, the contribution from Michelle Ballantyne was one of the most disgraceful speeches I have ever heard."Six minutes of pompous Victorian moralising, that would have been better suited to the pages of a Dickens novel."And to suggest that poverty should be a barrier to a family, that people who are poor are not entitled to any more than two children - what an absolutely disgraceful position."Ms Ballantynes words were also met with anger in Westminster today.Pete Wishart, the SNPs shadow leader of the House of Commons, told Parliament: "We dont want these th century, Tory, Victorian values in Scotland."There were simply appalling remarks in the Scottish Parliament yesterday when the Conservatives social security spokesperson, Michelle Ballantyne, said on the two-child benefit cap that it is fair that people on benefit cannot have as many children as they like."A comment that has simply appalled and shocked mainstream opinion in Scotland.The condemnation has come from across party ides.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard describing Ms Ballantynes words as abhorrent, nasty and archaic.He added: "The reality is that the Scottish Tories stand behind every blow of austerity and every cruel welfare cut that has been implemented by the UK Tory government - from the bedroom tax to the rape clause."These comments should be retracted and Michelle Ballantyne should apologise."

title: voters-to-go-to-polls-in-irish-presidential-election
story: Voters will go to the polls in Ireland today to elect the countryrsquos next president.Polling stations across the country will open at am and remain open until pm to give people the opportunity to cast their ballot.More than . million people are entitled to vote in  constituencies.The constituency with the single largest electorate in the country is Donegal, with more than , people registered to vote.This is closely followed by Tipperary with some ,, and Wexford with more than ,.In Dublin, more than , people are eligible to cast their ballot in the capitalrsquos  constituencies.The constituency with the smallest electorate is Dublin Central with , voters.Six candidates are vying for the highest office in the state.They are incumbent President Michael D Higgins, Senator Joan Freeman, Sinn Fein MEP Liadh Ni Riada, and three businessmen ndash Sean Gallagher, Gavin Duffy and Peter Casey.The electorate will also be asked on the ballot paper whether they want to remove the offence of blasphemy from the Irish constitution.Most islanders have already had their say as voting got under way on  islands off the coast of counties Donegal, Mayo and Galway on Thursday, a day ahead of the rest of the country.Garda Sgt John Gallagher and presiding officer Carmel McBride deliver a ballot box to Inishbofin Island The island with the largest number of registered voters is Inis Mor, Co Galway, where  people were able to cast ballots.There were five islands in Co Donegal where voting took place, including the largest, Arainn Mhor.Ballot boxes were brought by the Irish Defence Forces to some of the islands by ferry and to others by helicopter.At Inishbofin off the coast of Co Donegal, the ballot box arrived by helicopter before being carried by a Garda officer, accompanied by local presiding officer Carmel McBride, to a community centre to allow islanders their chance for a say in who will become the next president of Ireland.There was a similar procedure on Tory Island, where a Garda officer carried a ballot box to a school and voting was opened to the public.The ballot boxes were then collected on Thursday afternoon from the islands following voting.Islanders traditionally vote a day before the rest of the mainland to ensure there is no delay in transferring the ballot boxes to the mainland in time for the count.Some , islanders are eligible to vote in this yearrsquos election.About  live on islands off the coast of Cork, but they had to wait until Friday to vote, like the rest of the electorate.Douglas Hyde became Irelandrsquos first president in .Mr Higgins is the countryrsquos ninth president. He was elected in .Four presidents have served for two terms, or  years in total. They were Sean T OrsquoKelly, Eamon de Valera, Patrick Hillery and Mary McAleese.The Irish Government has appealed for people to use their vote but turnout is not expected to be as strong as the abortion referendum earlier this year.Count staff will begin sorting and collating the ballot papers at count centres across the country from am on Saturday.A result is expected by Saturday evening, or by early Sunday at the latest..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Voters to go to polls in Irish presidential election

title: dale defeated as poor form continues
story: Both sides were surprised to find Campbeltown#s Meadows pitch resembling a hay field with large clumps of cut grass.Carradale suffered the worst start when, after  seconds, a long lofted ball fell to the Uni#s number eight and he punched it home from eight yards.With a mix of experience, in the form of Euan McIlroy and youth with five schoolboys in the team, the goal seemed to motivate #Dale and they lted their game.Gregor Croll caused many problems in the Uni defence and equalised in the th minute to score #Dale#s first goal in three matches.In the nd minute, Matthew Lang, , playing his debut #Dale game had a great chance to give the home side the lead.Working with a through ball from Johnny McCormick, his first shot was saved by the goalie, he hit it again on the rebound and it was cleared from the line by a defender.At half-time with a - score line the game was either sides to win. It was not to be, four minutes in, a shot from the right shot across and passed the low ing McKellar.In the final  minutes the McFadyens sponsored #Dale threw caution to the wind in a :: formation. Two chances fell to Robert McGarrie and Robert McKinlay but they failed to capitalise.A couple of times #Dale were caught on the break but Mckellar stopped both attempts.In the dying embers Uni scored their third, before both teams headed for the Commercial Bar and pies from sponsor Billy Brodick at Food for Thought.Euan McIlroy was the referee#s choice for man of the match and Archie Johnston sponsored the match ball.All Carradale players and officials are thinking of Daniel Docherty. title: letter recycling struggles
story: When Campbeltown#s recycling scheme started I thought it was a good idea and have taken part since the beginning.For the past few years I have lived in a very small house with only two rooms, no hallways or cupboards.For that reason the only place I can keep the recycling clear plastic bag is in the shower. This is hard for me as I am disabled and struggle to take it in and out when I use the shower.At my former address the replacement bags were thrown into the garden at collection time. This was fine as the garden was fenced in and evenit was windy the bags would blow about the garden but not blow away.Where I currently live the front door is right on the pavement which is only about  inches wide.You would think it would be easy just to put the bags through the letterbox, but no, despite asking and even pleading with workers, to put them through the letterbox, they continuously throw them on the ground and I do not get the bags as they blow away.The last time my recycling was collected two weeks ago I was watching for the workers coming so I could get the bags handed to me.It was early and as the bags were outside I took a shower. Unfortunately, as I exited the shower, the van approached.I rushed as much as I am able but by the time I reached the door they had gone and left just one fresh bag.I had put out three full of recycling. I shouted to the man who was a vit further down the street but he did not appear to hear.In one of the first storms of the autumn, wearing just a T shirt, trousers and slippers with wet hair I followed them down the street, shouting at him to wait.Eventually half-way along the street he stopped and turned.I was dumbfounded when he said: #I heard you the first time you shouted. If you had said excuse me, I would have stopped, but I do not stop when someone shouts.#I was totally exhausted in the high wind and rain and felt asI was going to collapse. I came back in and just sat and cried.I have had enough, even to get them to leave the number of replacement bags is a struggle but it is a lot worse having to chase them down the street.This ignorant man should be doing behind the scenes work and not mixing with the public.I will not be recycling any more the struggle is just too much.Name and address supplied.

title: pupils threadbare squad full of holes
story: Kinross Scottish Amateur Cup nd RoundThe Pupils never really got going in this cup-tie, ending the game as second best to a moderately talented visiting side.Kinross were fortunate to be confronted by a uncharacteristically tame performance from the McFadyen sponsored home favourites.Lacking the key elements of drive, determination and quick controlled possession, the home side, playing with a threadbare squad due to injury and call-offs  used the long ball far too often in the first half.During the first twenty minutes the Pupils had territorial advantage, but were never able to string enough passes together to make a telling impact on the game.With the visitors hardly an attacking force, the home crowd was shocked when Kinross unexpectedly grabbed the lead shortly before half time.It’s ironic given that the Pupils back four seemed to be on top of their game, that one mistake should prove so costly.There seemed little danger, but the ball was lost in a crucial area and turned across goal for the incoming forward to score with the visitor’s only shot of the whole first half.The second half began disastrously for the home side, a through ball exposing the last line of defence whose first real action was to pick the ball out of the net.Given what went before, it was unimaginable that the Pupils were two goals behind at this stage the visitor’s ‘smash and grab’ tactics a complete contradiction to their earlier failure to attack.With the confidence of an unexpected but comfortable two goal cushion, the Fe League side turned the screw by controlling possession from the back.Mistakes had cost the home side dear, and, for the first time in the match the visitors looked like a team heading for the next round of the Scottish Cup!The home side tried desperately to retrieve the situation, but gaps appeared at the back as they threw caution to the wind.The keeper, young Alastair Ferguson, saved the day by fisting clear inside the six yard box, a timely intervention which kept the Pupils in the game at a crucial stage.Almost immediately, the home side were awarded a penalty kick on the back of a wild challenge in the box, and Gary Grumoli drove the ball into the net.Sensing blood, the Pupils powered forward at last using the ball to good effect with some fine possession football.However, it proved a  dawn and only a prequel to another defensive mistake which resulted in the visitor’s restoring their two goal cushion via a poacher’s finish from point blank range.In a breathtaking finish, the Pupils gained a second penalty with minutes remaining however, resisting the urge to change the kicker, Gary Grumoli placed his second effort to the keeper’s opposite side, only to see his kick saved dramatically.It was the final act of an uninspiring, but ultimately exciting game.The Pupils will try to put the cup disappointment behind them when they travel to play old foes, Hillington, in a league fixture tomorrow.Ellis Robertson played a solid game in the centre. _cpupilsvkinrossRyan Deans seemed not to select top gear after this early strike. _cpupilsvkinross

title: letter thanks to sale volunteers
story: The Rotary Club of Campbeltown would like to thank the Courier for reporting its recent Sale of the Century.The club is extremely grateful for all the help received from non-Rotarians and we wish to  thank these people publicly.First of all there are our friends in the Inner Wheel Club of Campbeltown who kept up a supply of tea, coffee, soft drinks, filled rolls and biscuits throughout the day.I don#t think that we could survive without this support and as ever we are grateful to all the Inner Wheel ladies.I will not go into detail of what everyone did, but the following people helped with transporting furniture to the hall and with deliveries afterwards: James Martin, Kintyre Recycling, Malcolm Ronald, Stewart McMillan, Stephen Chinn, Dillon Cox and Scott Edgers.Archie Houston checked all the electrical goods and Anne Leith attended to printing the catalogues.The following people helped at the Bric-a-brac stall, Marion Bell, Maureen Mathieson, Iain Ronald, John Barford and I must not forget the hall keeper.If I have missed anyone, I sincerely apologise.  We do value all the help that is given to us.At a subsequent meeting of the Rotary Club, there was discussion about the next sale and whether or not there should be one in the spring of .It was unanimously decided that there should not be another sale until the autumn of next year.Because of this, there will be no collections of furniture during the winter, but these will resume in April .A reminder will appear in the Courier about that time and this will also be publicised on social media.Last but by no means least, we would thank the public of Campbeltown and Kintyre for their continued support, which enables us to help others locally, nationally and internationally.Agnes Stewart,The Rotary Club of Campbeltown.

title: thought for the week october 12 2018
story: This is what it said, #Quieter Hour. Every Saturday from am to am, we are making this store a calmer and quieter environment.#I wondered how this could be achieved.Will people not chat  Will children not scream or shout  Will the people on the tills not talk to the customers This has intrigued me and I am interested in this search for quietness.Certainly in the cities it#s not easy to get away from noise as it#s everywhere.Cars, buses, trains, music blasting from every shop, and masses of people make it dficult to find the quiet centre of our lives.I thought again how fortunate we are in Argyll, where that quiet centre is within everyone#s reach – on a deserted beach, in a quiet garden, on a hilltop, in any of our wee country churches which are always open.It is also dficult in this age of gadgets to find calmness in our minds, to still our thoughts, to set aside tablets and iphones, Facebook and Twitter, and just be still.How do we connect with our inner being, with Godwe wish to,we are never quiet There is a lovely hymn by Shirley Erena Murray, which begins#Come and find the quiet centrein the crowded le we lead,find the room for hope to enter,find the space where we are freed:clear the chaos and the clutter,clear our eyes that we may seeall the things that really matter,be at peace, and simply be.#May we all find that deep peace Jesus promised us.

title: letter cheapest rest fix chosen
story: The recent engineering works, carried out by BEAR Scotland for the Scottish government, to try to solve the problems at the Rest and Be Thankful have clearly failed their first test.Those out working on the hillside in appalling conditions have done their best, as have Western Ferries.The problem is that the government did not invest the cash required to solve the problem.The government chose the cheapest of the options presented to them by consultants.They were warned repeatedly that this cheap solution would not keep the road open, but they chose to ignore these warnings.When the Old Military Road was first suggested as the route for an emergency relief road, they were warned that debris would fall down the hillside and block it. They ignored this warning too.The relief road should follow the route of the forest track on the southern slopes of the glen.Let’s hope that this time the message actually gets through.The government must invest the money required to keep the A open.If they don’t, the economy of Argyll and Bute will suffer even more damage.Alan Reid,Cowal Councillor, Fairhaven,Dunoon.

title: letter saga of a83 rest closures must end
story: Yet again the A is closed because of a landslip at the Rest and Be Thankful.Having been a resident in Argyll for  years I have lost count of the times this road has been affected by landslips.A #sticking plaster# is constantly used to try to resolve the situation and has absolutely no effect.I dread to think of the cost of trying to sort out this situation over the years by continually attempting to shore up the hillside.Given the increasingly volatile weather in the locality it is never going to recty the problem.When the cost to date is considered and the fact that the Old Military Road was upgraded at great expense and was not used last week, it is time the authorities bit the bullet and stopped pussyfooting around.In Europe there are endless tunnels providing safe passage through many routes and cost does not seem to be an issue.The only solution is to build a tunnel or is the population of Argyll too small and insignicant to warrant the expense Our elected politicians do not seem to care about the incredible disruption this continuing saga has on the welfare of the area.Keith Abendroth,High Askomil,Campbeltown.

title: the italian superstar from the corner caff
story: Every few years the daily papers re-tell the amazing story of an international footballer netted by Campbeltown Pupils.But the tale, with its many Kintyre connections and surviving bloodline legacy, the subject of a -page chapter in Alex McKinven#s authoritative Campbeltown football history: #Kit and Caboodle,# has never been explored by the Courier.Alex wrote: #In  the Grumoli family from the village of Renaio near Barga settled in Campbeltown.#Fourteen years before, in Falkirk, Leo Grumoli#s nephew, Giovanni #aka Johnny# Moscardini, was born and learned to play his football on the Scottish streets.Italy sided with the allies, in World War One, and Moscardini, aged  in , headed #home# to sign up with the crack mountain Alpini corps which was battling the Austo-Hungarian forces.He was wounded at the Battle of Caporetto and while recuperating in Sicily ed to the beautul game.Postwar he played in Barga where his games were watched by a scout from the Union Sportiva Lucchese.The following year he was the league#s top scorer and in  was capped for Italy, scoring the nation#s only goal in his debut match, a - draw with Switzerland.His odyssey continued with a tour of South America in . In all he was to score seven goals in nine international appearances.Football though, in the poverty stricken Italy of the s, recovering from the war, was not the mega-rich game of today and often the players survived by being paid in kind rather than cash.It has never been possible to eat fame and in , aged , he arrived in Campbeltown with his we Tecla, to help out at his uncle#s café.Unlikely as it may seem Johnny was still fit and pleased to be given the chance to pull on the white jersey of the Campbeltown Pupils for the seasons of   and  .He was an instant hit with the fans, a deadly dribbler with a powerful shot and he terrorised defences, at the Showfield, where Smith Park now stands, just behind the old jail.Having paid back his family, for subsidising his footballing le in Italy, two years later he moved to set up his own business in Prestwick.It must be something in the blood as Shaun, Paul and Gary Grumoli have all pulled on that same white shirt, to occasionally dazzle the Toon, at their club, which will celebrate its numerical centenary in .Back in Barga #Mosca# was never forgotten and the stadium is named in his honour.Johnny#s great nephew, former Campbeltown Grammar art teacher, Ronnie Togneri remembers a historic trip, in , to the Tuscan town, when he was  and his great uncle was .Ronnie said: #We watched the  World Cup final at Onesti#s café in the Barga square.#Most people did not have televisions at home and the large café was packed.#When we entered everyone stood and clapped Johnny and he gave a running commentary for the whole match.#Johnny was a Paolo Rossi or his era.#Johnny#s son Anthony, who passed away this year aged , in Liverpool, was born at  Main Street and went on to Glasgow School of Art before  becoming a renowned architect.Johnny Moscardini in Italian colours. title: giant-sponge-of-mosses-tackling-air-pollution-in-musselburgh
story: Air pollution in the centre of the Honest Toun has long been a cause for concern.Now, a giant sponge of mosses has been put in place on High Street, outside the police station, in the hope of cutting nearby pollution by close to a third.CityTree has been developed by German green technology firm Green City Solutions who say the combination of mosses in the structure can filter air pollutants - including nitrogen dioxide - from the surrounding air by up to  per cent.Derek Oliver of East Lothian Council described the structure as a "innovative approach"to tackling air quality issues.He added: "It is anticipated to raise awareness and influence behavioural change around pollution and climate change. We will seek public opinion following the pilot period.The East Lothian CityTree has been funded by the Scottish Government through the East Central Scotland Vehicle Emissions Partnership and has been installed in the designated Air Quality Management Area of Musselburgh High Street for an initial four-month pilot period.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet member for environment, added: ldquoIt is particularly appropriate that we are installing this CityTree at the start of Climate Week Scotland  and it will be interesting to see what impact it will have on air pollution in Musselburgh High Street."A number of measures have been outlined in the Musselburgh Air Quality Action Plan to tackle poor air quality including introducing new technology, aiming to reduce vehicle emissions, and encouraging sustainable travel options."Whether as an inidual, business or school, we can all play a part in taking action to improve our environment and I hope the CityTree will act as a focus for future ideas.The installation powers itself via solar , and rainwater is collected and automatically redistributed using a built-in irrigation system. This provides ideal conditions for the mosses to grow in an urban environment.East Lothian is the second local authority in Scotland to have a CityTree, following Glasgow City Council.CityTree technology has also been installed in Berlin, Paris, Brussels, Hong Kong, Amsterdam, Oslo, London and Newcastle.

title: decision-soon-on-the-quay-plans
story: Amanda Chisholm, the independent reporter appointed to determine the appeal on behalf of Scottish Ministers, carried out an inspection of the site at Fisherrow Harbour last month.Lodged by Simply Musselburgh Care Limited, the appeal followed East Lothian Councilrsquos refusal of a plan to convert the former leisure complex, restaurant andsuites into a -bed nursing home.Ms Chisholm is now preparing her decision, a copy of which will be sent to all parties involved and published on the Planning and Environmental Appeals Divisionrsquos website.A meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee in June regarding The Quay, owned by Dr Charan Gill, ended with a near-unanimous decision to reject the nursing home proposal.Only Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning committee convener, backed council officialsrsquo recommendation to approve the plan.Local groups including Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership, and Musselburgh Conservation Society, among others, are calling for the appeal to be thrown out., Musselburgh Area Partnership, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, and the Musselburgh Business Partnership are calling for the appeal to be thrown out.

title: teachers-time-in-turkey-inspires-her-debut-novel
story: Set in the Turkish capital Istanbul, Dr Margaret Halliday chose the location for her book as she worked as a teacher in the country for seven years.She decided to take up writing seriously five years ago when she was unable to live the same lestyle because of multiple sclerosis .An avid writer of diaries throughout her le, during which she saw the world, she planned to expand them into short stories when she retired.Dr Halliday, , who lives near Fisherrow, said: ldquoIrsquom excited about my first novel being published.ldquoAfter writing three memoirs, I wanted to try fiction as I had completed an Open University creative writing course.ldquoTaking the advice, lsquoyou should write about what you know,rsquo I chose Turkey for the setting as I worked there for seven years.The Belly Dancer is a tragicomic romantic thriller set mainly in Istanbul in the early s.Gemma, a young English woman, finds herself involved in more than just teaching English soon after her arrival in Turkey. Her love of belly dancing leads her into a relationship with the beautul Fatima as well as plunging her into a sinister, Mafia-run drugs operation.Dr Halliday said: ldquoI did not, however, belly dance or get involved with the Turkish Mafia and drug dealing ndash these had to be researched!ldquoLike Gemma, the heroine, I did teach English and visited Termal regularly, wallowing in the sparsquos waters just like her, as well as indulging in the occasional massage.ldquoNow I am putting together a collection of short stories, working title, Stranger than Fiction, about some of my weirder travel experiences. I have a character who Irsquod like to write another novel about but need to work on the plotrsquos development.Dr Halliday has published three autobiographical books ndash Prana Soup, an Indian Odyssey, which describes her travels around India Good Vibrations, which tells the story of a single s mum in Scotland and WWOOFing North and South, which relates her experience as a worldwide worker on organic farms in Scotland and New Zealand.Born in England in  with ldquogreen fingers and itchy feet, Dr Halliday undertook a yearrsquos training in Hastings Alexandra Park, followed by a horticultural course at the West of Scotland Agricultural College. She fell in love with Scotland, married a Scotsman and raised two children while working in scientic research and studying up to doctorate level.She qualied as a teacher of biology and chemistry and taught in ious schools and colleges in Edinburgh.Dr Halliday said her marriage broke up in , partly because of her ldquoitchy feet, and she went to live in Istanbul in , where she taught biological sciences at Marmara University for five years.After that, she taught English in Budapest and Damascus, exploring the countries and their environs in her holidays. Then she ed to Turkey and taught biology at a school for gted children near Istanbul.Her books are available via Amazon.as ebook and paperbacks.

title: housing-bid-at-edenhall
story: Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland Limited is seeking East Lothian Council approval for the housing within the walled garden of historic Pinkieburn House, which was designed by renowned Scottish architect John Dick Peddie.The site, which was associated with the estate of the Lindsay family in the early th century, became disused in  following NHS Lothianrsquos decision to relocate services to the newly developed Musselburgh Primary Care Centre.The residential development would include  new homes for private sale, which range from four to six-bedroom detached homes.The th century buildings on the site would be ldquosympathetically restored to provide  new luxury apartments and homes.There would be a further  new affordable homes, providing one-bed apartments to three-bed terraced houses, ldquoensuring a wide mix of new homes for Musselburgh.A statement from the company added: ldquoThis will help address the critical need for new high-quality housing in the town ndash with careful planning and contextual design leading to the creation of communities that are designed to reflect the sitersquos local heritage.ldquoStewart Milne Homes intend to deliver a high-quality development, based around the unique heritage assets of the restored and converted listed buildings at Edenhall, including Pinkieburn House, the stables and gardenerrsquos cottage.ldquoCareful consideration has been given to the look and feel of this development to provide a sense of community and legacy.ldquoThe proposed residential development will involve conversion of the listed buildings to form flatted apartments, and extended cottage and other linked villas, along with new build houses for sale where within the site.ldquoThis will be an exciting opportunity to prevent the buildings and wider estate falling into further disrepair, and ultimately bring the setting back into appropriate residential use. Restoration and repair work will be conducted on a like for like basis, using materials to match the existing historic fabrics.It added: ldquoTo allow for high quality flood management, road access and opening the area for better daylight, some tree management work will be required.The site is allocated for residential development in the Proposed East Lothian Local Development Plan.The proposed housing development would be served by the existing access from Edenhall Road, with the existing junction widened through relocation of the gate piers.Gerry More, managing director of Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland, said: ldquoFollowing our initial public consultation and exhibition two years ago, our proposals have been welcomed by the local community.ldquoOur vision is to create new communities that are fit for st century living, whilst incorporating traditional values and features.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, group chairwoman Irene Tait said the last time she was at the site it was ldquoall overgrown.She added: ldquoIt was horrible and dangerous, so it needs something done to it. They have got security measures but it becomes a danger for local children, although theyrsquore not supposed to be there.

title: schools-head-of-drama-sacked-following-disturbing-allegations
story: Daniel McLean-Steel, , was suspended by the headmaster of Loretto School in Musselburgh three weeks ago.Dr Graham Hawley contacted parents last week, the Courier has learnt, to inform them that Mr McLean-Steelrsquos employment had been ldquoterminated.Mr Hawley said: ldquoThe investigation has necessarily been a complex, detailed and thorough undertaking, and we have worked as expeditiously as we have been able.ldquoUnderstandably, during this period there have been a range of concerns and questions, and I hope that our personal responses to each have, wherever possible, served to inform and reassure you and others in so far as we have been able.ldquoThe investigation has now been completed, and the outcome of the process has been to terminate the employment of a member of staff, Mr Daniel McLean-Steel.The headmaster told parents he expected questions about the ldquonature of the complaint.But he said he was not revealing any details in his statement ldquofor legal reasons, despite also confirming that there was no active police investigation.In a previous statement, issued on September , the headmaster said that he had been ldquodeeply disturbed by these allegations" and took them "very seriously".Mr Hawley has now said: ldquoAs I have already indicated in my letter and statement of Wednesday  September , the allegations were in relation to behaviours which are unacceptable and have no place in our community, and the investigation has found this to be the case.ldquoI can confirm there is no active police case in association with this matter at this time, and I can also confirm the allegations presented did not relate to current pupils of the school."For legal reasons, it is not appropriate that I make further comment on this.The headmaster told parents he has begun a recruitment process to find a new head of drama. He also urged parents to contact himthey have any further concerns.When the allegations emerged Mr Hawley said he had alerted the Care Inspectorate.A spokesman for the Care Inspectorate said: ldquoWe are aware of an alleged incident at this school and are satisfied the school have responded appropriately.ldquoWe remain in close contact with the school. Anyone with a concern about a care service is encouraged to contact us.Mr McLean-Steel could not be reached for comment.
